SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable senators who participated in the second reading debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . Native title is a very recent issue for most Australians. It is complex and it evokes deep emotions, because nothing is more fundamental than how we share the land, and native title is very different from other forms of Australian land tenure.

SPEECH.PARA: The government's bill follows the High Court's recognition of native title rights as part of Australia's common law and passage of the 1993 Native Title Act. In 1993, we in the coalition parties thought that the act was inadequate and unworkable. It has also failed to deliver real outcomes, particularly to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. After almost four years, over 660 claims, and over $210 million of taxpayer funded expenditure, the only judicial determination of native title on mainland Australia is for a small piece of land at Crescent Head in New South Wales.

On 23 December 1996, almost 12 months ago, the High Court decided in the Wik case, by a four to three margin, that pastoral leases do not necessarily extinguish all native title. This decision relates in complex ways with the existing Native Title Act, which was simply not designed to deal properly with coexisting rights and interests in land.

This interaction, and not simply the Wik decision itself, produced serious legal uncertainties. For example, the current act could mean that activities which are legal under pastoral leases or permits and essential to pastoral businesses would be impermissible if native title could be effected. The act could also effectively reverse the Wik finding that pastoral leaseholders' rights prevail over native title rights.

Clearly, the decision has widespread implications for native title holders, for resource based industries like mining, petroleum and fishing, for pastoralists and farmers, and for governments. Leading up to the release of our 10‐point plan in May this year, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) personally spent months in detailed consultation and discussion with all these interest groups to develop a fair and balanced framework for a Commonwealth legislative response to the Wik decision.

The Prime Minister resisted widespread calls for extinguishment of native title on pastoral lease land. Instead, he proposed a fair and sensible national framework which integrates the Wik decision into Australian land law management. The Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , based on that plan, respects and protects native title and allows claims over about 79 per cent of Australia's land area, including over pastoral leases. It also deals with workability issues arising from experience with the current act. In summary, the bill lets the Wik decision work.

Few opponents of the bill appear to accept or concede that substantial deficiencies in the current act must be remedied if coexistence of native title with other interests in land is to be accommodated in our legal system. This is because the conventional wisdom in 1993 was that native title would be found to exist in limited and remote parts of Australia, and would not be interacting with other interests. Since we now know this understanding to be wrong, the act must have a more appropriate future act regime, in particular for pastoral lease land. This is done by the bill.

A constant refrain from the opposition is that the bill lacks a proper constitutional foundation. The government has formal constitutional advice from the Solicitor‐General that the bill is entirely supported as a special law under the constitutional races power. The government recognises that the bill's constitutional validity is likely to be challenged, probably by our political opponents, just as the native title act itself was, unsuccessfully, challenged.

The government's firm view, supported by the opinion of the Solicitor‐General, is that the bill is not detrimental to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and is fully supported by the races power of the constitution. Political assertions about constitutionality should not prevent passage of the bill, any more than they prevented passage of the Native Title Act in 1993.

It has also been alleged by some that the bill overturns the decisions of the High Court in Mabo and Wik. The government absolutely rejects these allegations. The bill adopts the very test in Wik that native title has been extinguished to the extent that native title rights and interests are inconsistent with the grant of rights and interests to lessees. It is left to the courts to assess the extent of this inconsistency. The bill does not pre‐empt these decisions.

The bill provides—again, as the court held in Wik—that lessees rights prevail over any surviving native title rights. It implements this principle in the real world of practical primary production. I note that 81 per cent of Australians believe that farmers should be guaranteed that they can use the land they lease as needed.

Some people argue that the bill's validation provisions are not justified because government's should not have acted on the basis that native title was extinguished on pastoral leases. However, this assumption was supported by the High Court's decision in Mabo, by the Native Title Act itself, by the practice of the National Native Title Tribunal and by decisions of the Federal Court. It was also actively encouraged by the previous government. The coalition government believes that grants made on the basis of this legal assumption should be validated by legislation. It is just not possible to provide the necessary validity through agreements.

The bill's confirmation provisions are vital to ensuring certainty in areas of Australia where, on any reasonable assessment, native title as a matter of common law has been extinguished. The act currently leaves these issues to be determined by the common law. The bill will allow the extinguishment of native title to be confirmed in line with the decisions in Mabo and Wik. The government calls on the Senate to meet its obligations to provide Australians with certainty by supporting the bill's confirmation that freehold land and other titles which clearly grant exclusive possession extinguish native title. It would be unacceptable for the parliament not to support a bill which reiterates the views of the High Court.

The schedule to the bill includes types of agricultural, residential and commercial leases which the Commonwealth and the relevant state and territories believe, on the basis of a purely legal assessment, have conferred exclusive possession and have therefore extinguished native title. The schedule does not contain one pastoral lease or other lessor interests and specifically excludes mining leases.

The parliamentary joint committee has heard that the Commonwealth took a highly conservative approach to the development of the schedule. Some states and other interests strongly criticised the Commonwealth because certain tenures were not included. Some argue that this approach pre-empts the common law. But to leave these issues to be determined on a case by case basis by the courts would incur an enormous cost and leave enormous uncertainty. From the government's point of view, such a massive expenditure for little or no tangible benefit for Aboriginal people cannot be justified. Expenditure priority should be on determining claims on the 79 per cent of Australia where native title may have survived.

The proposed primary production amendments have been widely misunderstood, as shown by some opposition contributions to the debate in the House and the Senate. The fact is that the current act contains very limited mechanisms for managing future acts on pastoral leases. The bill makes it explicit for the first time that pastoralists can carry on primary production activities on the pastoral lease and that those activities prevail. State and territory governments can continue to authorise primary production activities. State and territory governments can continue to authorise pastoralists to carry on activities outside the farm area which are directly related to primary production activities on the lease. State and territories can continue to authorise the taking of natural resources from pastoral leases.

These acts will be subject to the non-extinguishment principle. This means that they cannot extinguish native title rights. These provisions do not confer any additional rights on pastoralists or any other person. The management of pastoral leases remains a matter for the relevant state and territory government, as it has always been throughout Australian history. The same applies for environmental controls. It is wholly inappropriate for native title legislation to be used as a substitute for proper environmental regulation and management. Moreover, contrary to some of the grossly inaccurate reporting in the past six months, the government's amendments will not result in a windfall for foreign pastoral leaseholders.

For future development on pastoral leases, the government's policy is to ensure that legitimate land management needs, such as for suburban developments, public infrastructure and agricultural developments, can be accommodated. It is hoped that this can be done through agreement with native titleholders and others. The bill's guaranteed legal certainty for agreements about native title encourages this approach. There may, how ever, be occasions when agreements cannot be reached. The bill ensures that the only way that native title can be extinguished in the future is by agreement or through non-discriminatory compulsory acquisition, with compensation on just terms.

There is little doubt that the Native Title Act as passed by this parliament in 1993 has caused delays in economic activity, particularly for resource development, at a significant opportunity cost for all Australians. Several senators have commented on the economic and commercial implications of the existing act's operations. The facts are these: of the 1,958 acts in Western Australia now subject to the full right to negotiate process, only 169 have been cleared for grant as at 24 October 1997. That is a clearance rate of about 8.6 per cent. The `greater than 90 per cent clearance rate' often quoted is for exploration and prospecting licences which have gone through the act's so-called expedited procedures. Under the act, these give indigenous people very little protection, unlike the provisions in our bill, which do provide that protection.

There has been a 19 per cent fall-off in exploration expenditure in Queensland in the last year, which is a matter of great concern to all Australians. My understanding is that about one-third of Queensland exploration titles are being held up because of uncertainty about native title. The nation simply cannot afford this cost.

So far as ministerial intervention and the right to negotiate process is concerned, the power is constrained by very strict criteria. The minister cannot intervene in the right to negotiate process at will. There has been criticism of the bill's provisions allowing the states and territories to apply their own alternative regimes on coexisting tenures. In these areas where native title can only coexist with other interests, the government considers it inappropriate to equate native title rights with full ownership rights.

There is widespread support for the bill's stronger legally certain agreements framework. A significant number of senators have indicated support for these provisions. Most interest groups recognise the potential for agreements to provide a lasting and workable resolution of native title, land use and coexistence issues at a local or regional level, either with or without government participation. Together with the bill's enhanced representative body scheme, the new agreement provisions give an attractive alternative to the more formal and adversarial processes for resolving native title related issues. There is also general agreement that the Native Title Act needs to have an effective registration test so that only meritorious claims can be registered and gain access to the very significant benefits that it provides. The bill's stronger registration test is to bring an end to the problem of overlapping and multiple claims that are dividing Aboriginal communities and deterring investment.

Allegations have been made that the government failed to consult on the bill and, in particular, did not negotiate its contents with indigenous groups. The government followed an open consultative process and, as far as possible, included all relevant interests in working towards the 10‐point plan. It developed the working draft bill, refined the bill for introduction into the parliament and developed the schedule of exclusive tenures attached to the bill. We had significant discussions with indigenous representatives, and the bill includes proposals put forward by them.

I commend the work of the parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund chaired by Mr Warren Entsch. The committee spent long hours hearing evidence in Canberra, Broome, Alice Springs and Cairns. The government appreciates the committee's very useful report as well as the time and effort of people and organisations around Australia in giving evidence and making submissions. The government gave serious consideration to the committee's majority report. This is reflected in amendments that we will be proposing to the bill. We also appreciate the consideration of the bill by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee chaired by my colleague Senator Eric Abetz. We acknowledge the submissions and evidence of constitutional experts. Again, there has been full government consideration of the committee's report, as reflected in our proposed amendments to the bill.

From my perspective, the current community and parliamentary debate seems more about fiction than about the facts of the bill and its actual contents. There has been far too much misrepresentation and posturing. There are far too few who have done the hard work to understand the bill, which we see as a fair balance regarding a range of competing interests.

This bill gives effect to and implements the Wik decision. It does not involve wholesale extinguishment of native title on pastoral lease land; it meets many of the concerns of indigenous groups. The government and the parliament must balance the aspirations of indigenous people with the needs of others in the community—in particular, elected local and state governments, farmers, pastoral lessees and workers in the mining industry. The government's bill is a practicable, workable, balanced solution to the manifest deficiencies of the Native Title Act. I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That it be an instruction to the committee of the whole that:

(a) the committee divide the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 to incorporate in a separate bill the proposed amendments in relation to indigenous land use agreements (subsections 24AA(3) and 24AB(1) and Subdivisions B to E of item 9 of Schedule 1) and the response to the High Court's decision in the Brandy case (items 2, 4, 5, 7, 8, 10 to 17, 19 (section 61 Divisions 2A and 3 of Part 3), 20 (sections 85, 85A and 86 and Divisions 1B and 1C of Part 4), 23, 26 to 39, 42 to 61 and 65 to 68 of Schedule 2); and
(b) the committee add to that bill enacting words and provisions for titles, commencements and Schedules.

The purpose of this motion is to split the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 into two bills. The first, which I understand has broad agreement and is relatively non-contentious, deals with the so-called Brandy amendments which seek to make the procedures in the Native Title Act consistent with the determination by the High Court in the Brandy case and in the sections dealing with indigenous land use agreements. The second bill, which obviously incorporates the balance of the bill now before us, contains measures on which there is substantial disagreement.

This proposal, which is a fall‐back position for the Greens in that we would have preferred the entire bill to be withdrawn by the government to allow for real consultation, would allow the non-contentious bill to be debated, given a third reading and sent to the House of Representatives for agreement. It would then come into effect before Christmas and not be tied up with the controversy and doubt that surrounds the balance of the government's native title bill.

This proposal is all about process. Firstly, the non-contentious aspects of the bill respond to the general concerns in both the indigenous community and the pastoral and mining industries about the processes in the Native Title Act. Honourable senators may recall that in 1993 the Greens (WA) clearly stated that the way the Native Title Act was constructed, the way it was drafted, made it very difficult to incorporate the principles of native title into the operation of other titles and other land holdings in Australia. Secondly, this proposal has been put forward for consideration by the Senate as a means of avoiding the acrimony and division that is already evident in the community about the balance of the bill. The balance of the bill can, of course, be dealt with on its merits, and it is my opinion that it does not have a great many.

What is needed is proper consultation with the communities around Australia who are going to be affected by these changes to native title law in this country. I would say, quite clearly, that even those people in the pastoral industry have not had much chance to have much intimate knowledge of what the bill is about and why it is or is not necessary in parts.

The Greens have always maintained that there should be a consensus based approach to most public policy decisions. This approach is based on the belief that it is better to take the time to properly consult with those affected by public policy and reach broad based agreement than create the sort of division and disagreement that has been evident in the government's legislative response to the Wik judgment.

As Senator Boswell stated in his speech during the second reading debate, in many cases there has been a degree of coexistence and harmony in rural communities in recent times. He seems to argue that the Wik judgment has created disharmony. The Greens would argue that it is the government's response to the Wik judgment that has created most of the disharmony. An approach in which the government determined its so-called 10-point plan in consultation with state governments and industry groups and then presented it to Aboriginal leaders largely as a fate accompli is hardly a consultative approach.

There has been too much pressure to get a quick response to deliver so-called certainty to the pastoral and mining industries. I would argue that, if this is what the government wants, it has gone about it entirely the wrong way. This bill is likely to create greater uncertainty due to its shaky legal foundations and because it has not been developed in a spirit of compromise and in a proper consultative framework.

This proposal to split the bill gives the government the best of both words. It gives them not only some amendments in procedures for native title, some improvements in procedures for native title, but also time to go away and properly consult with all stakeholders, especially Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders who missed out on the first round. It is not our preferred position. Our preferred position was to withdraw the bill. That has been defeated by a Senate which seems intent at the moment on pushing through this legislation. However, I would like to see whether there is support for dealing with and progressing the relatively contentious elements of the bill and then dealing with the rest of the bill on it merits. I commend my motion to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government clearly does not support this motion, which is really all about splitting up the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . Of course, we categorically reject the assertion that there was not sufficient consultation with all parties involved. There is a range of competing interests in an area as complex and difficult as this. In reaching a compromise, inevitably no one interest group was ever likely to achieve everything they wanted. In putting together this package, farmers have not got what they wanted, the mining industry has not got everything it wanted, nor have state and territory governments and indigenous representatives got everything they wanted.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill is a compromise worked out over many months. It is now nearly a year since the Wik decision. It is four years since the Native Title Act came into effect. The problems with this act were and are manifest. The previous government itself introduced a bill to amend the Native Title Act some two years ago and still there have been no amendments. So this is a matter of urgency in relation to the whole nation. We believe all elements of this bill are essential and should be dealt with, and we oppose the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition also opposes the motion, but I have to say we share the frustration of Senator Margetts and others about the legislation. It may have been a year since Wik, but I have to say that it has been a year of frustration for a lot of people with an interest in this area—particularly indigenous Australians who, unlike in Senator Minchin's assessment and appreciation, do not feel as if they have been adequately consulted. They may have had meetings with them, but they do not feel as if their voice has been heard in the process.

SPEECH.PARA: We on this side of the parliament and in the opposition have agreed to the legislation going ahead through the second reading stage but, in doing so, we have made it very clear outside this place—as I make it very clear now—that we believe this legislation needs a quite comprehensive overhaul. Its implication, its overreach and its unintended consequences that go too far are for us sufficient evidence that, if this legislation goes through, it will provide an enormous mess for the system to handle.

BREAK.PARA: Though the process has been rushed, though the issues are wide ranging—you can see that from the fact there are almost 700 amendments before the Senate to be discussed in the next week or few weeks—it will be an exhaustive process, but we feel we can actually proceed with the legislation at this stage. Let us see how progress goes over the next week or so. We would like to be able to give it that comprehensive overhaul that I mentioned a few seconds ago over the next few days and we will see at the end of it what evolves through this process, but I do not think we should be stalling the process at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear what Senator Bolkus is saying but this is not trying to stall the debate; it is actually trying to facilitate it. As has been stated from the outset of this debate, not all of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 is bad. There are, and we acknowledge, some necessary and unavoidable amendments. Some of these have been thrust upon us due to decisions in the High Court—most notably the Brandy decision, which clarified the position of judicial power vis-a-vis the constitution and Commonwealth tribunals. This is uncontentious.

SPEECH.PARA: Other amendments have broad agreement and indeed the consent of the indigenous people. For example, the indigenous land use agreements have been drafted in large part in concert with the indigenous people. Furthermore, the notion of agreements and negotiation, rather than litigation and extinguishment, underpins what the Democrats say is the way forward for native title. People should have the opportunity to sit down and get on with coexisting. Actually, in the end, that is what it is all about.

People who have no vested interests in getting on with indigenous people have found the agreement process as an anathema to how they see the world, but there is much more at stake here. Reconciliation is dependent upon us sitting down and discussing on an equal basis our common interests and individual concerns. I really cannot understand why the government continues to almost project Aboriginal people as though they are not part of Australia—as though they are some separate and almost foreign group.

There can be no other option to coexistence and reconciliation if what we want is a united and harmonious Australia. The Democrats believe that the issues in this debate will be much clearer if those non-contentious general agreement areas are separated from the more abhorrent prospects in the bill. We will be supporting Senator Margetts's motion to have the bill divided and dealt with in manageable parts. We believe that clarity in the public eye will be achieved if we can separate the good parts of the bill from the attempted injustice being perpetrated by the Howard government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I also support this motion moved by Senator Margetts. It is very important. There is an expectation that at the end of the day there is going to be disagreement in the Senate about the amendments to the government's Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . In short, we are going to find that the government's legislation will be amended—certainly, I hope that is the case—to the point where the government is not going to accept it.

SPEECH.PARA: The process will be that the very much amended bill will go back to the House of Representatives and will then be sent back here. There will be disagreement between the chambers and, in effect, the government will reject the amendments. If that is the case, the whole legislation then would come back here some time next year, and there has been speculation that it may even lead to a double dissolution and an election later next year, triggered by that disagreement. The outcome of all that will be no progress as far as native title is concerned.

What Senator Margetts's motion does is says, `Let's at least get together those things which all components of the Senate agree upon and have them enacted into law to facilitate native title and to give some certainty to all parties involved coming out of the Brandy case and so on.' That is a very sensible and logical way to go. Let us at least pass the non-contentious bits into law, while the points of disputation take their course—and it may be a very long course, indeed.

BREAK.PARA: I do not understand why the Labor Party are not supporting this motion. It is entirely sensible. It is mature, good sense. It is going to help leaseholders. It is going to help indigenous people. It is going to help developers, wherever they might be. It has nothing going against it. So I do not understand why the Labor Party and, indeed, the government are not supporting it. It is almost as if it is all or nothing and we have lost sight of the ultimate goal, which is to, as best we can, facilitate the country's move towards settling this issue.

It is going to be difficult. We should be passing those components of this very complex issue upon which everybody agrees, and here is the opportunity. The Labor Party should think again. The government should think again. It is sheer commonsense. Senator Margetts's motion ought to have the support of everybody in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put on the record a very short section from the introduction of the executive summary from the explanatory memorandum issued by the National Indigenous Working Group. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the preferred position of the National Indigenous Working Group that the Senate should reject the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997.

Given that we know that there are areas in the bill that will advance the process of agreements in working out and actually providing for the enjoyment of native title and which will provide the ability for people to come together and for healing to occur in Australia, I commend my motion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the government has indicated repeatedly, we are adopting the same approach adopted by you, Senator Bolkus, and now Mr Evans when in government: that legal professional privilege attaches to government legal advice. The government has received, in developing a bill of this kind, a range of legal and policy advice in addressing all the complex legal questions that it raises. We are satisfied, on the balance of the advice we have received from the range of sources, that the bill is not racially discriminatory. We are satisfied that it achieves its objectives in a non-racial discriminatory manner.

SPEECH.PARA: We are adopting exactly the same approach to the relationship between the Native Title Act and the Racial Discrimination Act as you did by preserving in the bill and, therefore, in the amended act section 7(1), which states:
Nothing in this Act shall affect the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act.

The advice that is relevant, of course, is that that goes to the constitutionality of the bill. Obviously the parliament should have advice on the question of whether it is valid to pass the law, and we have released that advice from the Solicitor-General. As to the range of other advices, that will not be released in accordance with practice adopted by your government. The government is entirely satisfied that the bill is not racially discriminatory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Minchin, you would also be aware of practice in the past which has allowed advice to, in fact, be released by government. The government has often released advice in respect of legal matters and advice provided by the Attorney-General's Department or other solicitors acting for the government. I ask you to take that into account. Are you saying to us that you are essentially choosing to ignore the order of the Senate?

This bill has been developed over a range of time. We commenced this process back in January. Various stages have been dealt with and legal advices and other policy advices have been received on various stages of the bill and various issues related to the bill. —Senator Minchin, you say that you will not release any advice, but my understanding is that legal advice has, in fact, been provided by government. TALK.START.PARA: —As I said before, we believe it is relevant in the face of the constant claims that the bill may be unconstitutional. We believe that in terms of public interest debate it is appropriate, given the constant clamouring that the bill has some constitutional doubt about it, to remove that doubt by releasing the official advice of the Solicitor-General, supported by David Jackson QC, to that effect. TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to labour this point this morning and I will not go on for too long, but I think what you have done, Senator Minchin, is basically substantiated my assertion to you: that you have released some advice. You claim that constitutionality is important, and obviously it is. I suppose what I would like to know and what the public would like to know is: why don't you think that conforming with our international obligations is a sufficiently important consideration for this parliament to weigh in assessing this legislation? TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the government takes quite seriously its international human rights obligations under the convention and also obviously in developing legislation that takes account of racial discrimination provisions. We have taken those matters into serious account in developing the bill and have obviously taken account of a range of advice on a whole range of issues dealing with those questions.

SPEECH.PARA: We are certainly very conscious of our obligations to ensure that legislation is not racially discriminatory taken as a whole and we can hold up our heads in the international arena. We believe that Australia can do so. This nation has and is dealing humanely and properly with the obvious disadvantage that Aboriginal people suffer and our government has put a tremendous and particular focus on dealing with the particular disadvantage of Aboriginal people in relation to health, housing, education and welfare.

We are conscious that governments over a period of time have dedicated 15 per cent of the nation to ownership or control by Aboriginal people. We are maintaining the indigenous land fund, which will provide $45 million every year for ever to enable Aboriginal people to buy land. So we believe that Australia has a very proud record and that this bill will consolidate that.

This bill does provide significant benefits to Aboriginal people. It continues to protect native title from its general defeasibility at common law by ensuring that in future native title can only be extinguished by agreement or by compulsory acquisition pursued in a non‐discriminatory manner and we have strengthened and reinforced the non‐discriminatory regime in relation to compulsory acquisition, because, of course, the current act already contains a compulsory acquisition regime.

Some of the argument in relation to native title on this issue pertains to validation. Of course, your act quite properly contained a validation regime, and that was appropriate and proper and should have been in it. Because of the circumstances you well understand, this act contains a much stricter and more limited validation regime applying to acts on pastoral lease land in the period 1 January 1994 to 23 December 1996. That is a matter that must be dealt with. We are convinced that the bill taken as a whole is clearly non‐discriminatory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not pursue this matter any further at this stage, other than to indicate that we will obviously keep on pursuing it next week. From my perspective, we can actually move on to other matters. I do not know if other senators want to pursue this at this particular stage.

SPEECH.PARA: By way of introduction I indicate that there have been discussions with the Greens, the Democrats and obviously with Senator Harradine. In respect of discussions with the Greens and the Democrats, we have tried to work out a way of facilitating debate here. I indicate that they will be handling these amendments in bundles. Bundles is probably the best way of doing so, because we can focus on the underlying principles related to any particular area and see how the amendments fit within them.

The agreement is that we may find from time to time as we address these clusters and bundles of amendments that all of us will not have to spend the allowable 15 or 20 minutes to present the case in respect of those clusters. You may find in some areas the Greens, the Democrats or the opposition will be presenting the case. We are trying to minimise prolonged debate in that respect. It is important to put that on the record at this particular stage as people might read the record at a later date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few general remarks in that vein. We have agreed with the structure of the debate and the 21 blocks and are happy to proceed on that basis. I do want to make some general comments.

SPEECH.PARA: The government, as has been made evident, was always prepared to consider amendments in the lead-up to the debate of this bill which we were satisfied improved the workability of the bill and were consistent with a well thought through and considered government policy. That is why, following consideration of the two parliamentary committee inquiries into the bill, we have developed some amend ments of our own which we will be moving during the committee stage, and which I would trust will find acceptance from the Senate.

Generally speaking, we wish to cooperate to ensure that the bill can be dealt with by the end of next week. We will not call unnecessary divisions where it is clear which way the matter is being decided. We do want to ensure the maximum time is available for consideration of the bill.

There are in number about 92 government amendments, but many of them are very technical and do not change the policy position of the bill, and therefore should not unduly take up too much time. We put out a detailed explanation of those amendments. As I say, we look forward to support from the opposition parties.

I would have to say on the record that we are in a difficult position now as a government in relation to amendments proposed by other parties. The ALP has some 350 amendments and the Democrats a similar number. We are looking forward to considering any amendments that Senator Harradine may propose and I am not sure about the Greens. We are talking about the consideration of some 800 amendments and what has been agreed to in principle is that we try to complete this by Thursday night next week.

The Democrat and opposition amendments are closely related to the indigenous working group paper on the bill and therefore have much in common. As you have said, you will be dealing with them in a joint manner, but where they diverge it becomes very complex.

Our difficulty is that we introduced this bill as a final bill nearly three months ago. The draft bill, which was substantially similar, has been available for five months. We are therefore in a difficult position given that all the amendments to the bill have really only been available for about 48 hours. This is such a complex area that we are not in a position to accept amendments on the run. The former government has criticised us for not supporting certain parts of the bill or debating the bill in 1993, therefore forcing the ALP to accept amendments to get the bill through that it might not otherwise have supported. All I am saying is that our attitude to amendments that we have had only 48 hours to consider is that we are simply not prepared to accept amendments on the run without having had an opportunity to fully consider any unintended consequences and the workability and practicality of so many amendments.

The Native Title Act is the most substantive and significant intervention by the Commonwealth government into the land management responsibilities of states and territories in the 97 years of the Federation. Therefore, the parliament has an absolute responsibility to make very certain that the decisions it makes in this area have clear and intended consequences and are practical in relation to the land management responsibilities which go on every day all day in every state jurisdiction by democratically elected governments with the prima facie sovereign right under our constitution to manage land in this country.

We have had a serious look at the ALP amendments. I think they take up about 80 per cent of the Democrat amendments. I have to say there are some real problems where we have major policy differences that would take a lot more time to work through, so it is not going to be possible for us to simply accept them. Where there is doubt we will simply not be able to accept those amendments because we are not going to allow a bill to go through this parliament which has massive unintended consequences for land administration in this country.

I thought it was important to set that scene in relation to our deliberation on the amendments. It is not a matter of the government being deliberately obstructionist. Given that three months after the bill was available we have 48 hours to consider 700 or 800 amendments—and we are all, I think, endeavouring to have this bill dealt with by the end of next week—I just wanted to set out the government's attitude to that practical matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a comment on the questions that were asked by Senator Bolkus and the answers given by the minister in relation to the legal advice that has been sought and given or not given in relation to this bill. It certainly was not a principle applied in terms of whether or not legal advice was provided. What seems to have been applied is a decision to selectively release those things which might just have scraped over the line in supporting the government's position. That is not a principle at all. It is not transparent. It is not solidly acting on any particular past practice. It is saying, `We will release what supports our argument. But if we seek advice and the advice says, "Wrong way, go back," we're not actually going to release that. We're going to stand behind some sort of secrecy principle that we did not actually apply to the legal advice that may just have scraped over the line in supporting our position.'

SPEECH.PARA: Quite a few of us heard the Solicitor‐General's position which he put to the Senate Legal and Constitution Committee. He spent, I think, the best part of 40 minutes not giving advice. In the last minute or so he said, `Well, if you want my advice I'll say it's constitutional but my advice isn't worth much.' That is the entire basis upon which this government is operating. The minister has indicated that the Solicitor‐General has indicated that the bill is beneficial to Aboriginal people. How he would know that without actually consulting with Aboriginal people is a little difficult for me to know. I think it is a bit difficult for the minister to know as well. He said, `We believe the bill is beneficial. However, we don't believe we're going to need the bill to be beneficial to use the race power in this bill.'

That is one of the greatest indictments of any government that I have heard since I have been in the Senate. What it means is that they might be prepared to go to the High Court and argue that you can produce a bill which is to the detriment of indigenous Australians and argue that the race power of the Australian constitution allows you to do that. What an indictment.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did the 1993 act do?

—Senator Ian Campbell says, `What did the 1993 act do?' The judgment in relation to the High Court decision when the Western Australian state government wasted such a huge amount of taxpayers' money on challenging the Native Title Act in the first place said that, on balance, because there was at least the perception of consent in relation to the 1993 act, the bill could be read to be beneficial. Some in the community would disagree that there was that perception. If you have not had consultation, if you have not had agreement with indigenous Australians, you could not possibly know. Certainly consent is taken into consideration when you look at the incidence of beneficiality. That has been argued by a roomful of QCs or certainly a number of the Qcs who gave evidence to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no way in the world that this government will be able to pay somebody to stand up for them in the High Court and argue that the bill as it is put has the consent of indigenous Australians. If they are saying that they have got a bill which indigenous Australians are happy with, I guess they did not go outside and see the sea of hands. I guess they kept their eyes closed. They were not hearing the very strident calls to withdraw the bill. They were not hearing the very strident calls to defeat the 10‐point plan. They were not hearing. We know they were not hearing. They did not take those views into consideration. They did not even see that it was necessary to sit down and work through those differences.

In the clear absence of consent, for anybody from the government to say, `We believe this bill is beneficial to indigenous Australians,' is the very epitome of dangerous and discriminatory paternalism. I do not think this is good enough in 1997.

I should mention that the Greens (WA) have spoken at length with members of the National Indigenous Working Group. We realise that, because they have not been taken into the consultation process, they have been put in a very difficult situation by the government. In that situation they looked at the fact that their first choice—that is, that the bill be defeated—would not be able to be achieved without the majority of the Senate backing them. Given that the majority of the Senate did not back them to defeat the bill, I guess they were left with the choice of trying to find a compromise. The compromise has consisted of working through the bill with parties in the Senate to make, as I have mentioned before, a silk purse out of a sow's ear—that is, to try to make something that is less discriminatory and less harmful to indigenous Australians out of the legislation that has been presented to them.

I would like to speak about the indigenous land use agreements, but I will not start speaking about them now because other senators may want to make initial comments before we get to look at the packages of amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on what Senator Minchin had to say about the government's ability to look at the amendments. The Australian Democrats have adopted the amendments prepared after long consultation with the indigenous working group which made a point of listening to, and indeed taking on board, the views of Aboriginal and other Australians from across the country, without the resources of a full department and without the resources of a range of draftspeople at their beck and call.

SPEECH.PARA: One would have hoped that the government, having had the last couple of days to look through the amendments, would have realised that lots of them are similar not only to the ones that the Labor Party have now moved but also, indeed, to the amendments of the Greens, who have been working with the body that is actually out there consulting. In other words, particularly over the weekend—as today we will be largely dealing with non‐controversial amendments—the government should work to have in front of us, by the time we get to the controversial amendments on Monday, any technical problems they envisage with the amendments to be moved by this side of the chamber. While it may be necessary to burn some midnight oil, I would hope that things can be organised so that, once we get into the more difficult areas as we move through the packages of amendments, we will be able to have the government's views, and hopefully—as many of our amendments are aimed at facilitating the operation of the original act—we will have government support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment on Senator Minchin's statement that the government will not be accepting amendments on the run. This is a very complex matter that we will be debating over the next week. It is inevitable that there will be amendments come up which are constructive, that people agree on, and that the government will find itself agreeing to, even if they are technical. For the minister to make a blanket statement that there will not be further amendments accepted is not to be cognisant of the way complex matters such as this inevitably lead to constructive amendments coming out of the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The government also chided the opposition, the Australian Democrats and the rest of us for not having produced the amendments until the last few days. But the government itself dumped 90 amendments or so on the table last night, and we have to deal with those. The government will have to deal with the amendments from this side of the place. This idea that suddenly the government will be unable to cope with the amendments that this legislation will lead to is very simplistic. The government has huge resources, including legal resources, that are not available to this side of the chamber. The government will have to deal with amendments, including amendments that arise as the next few days unfold.

What Senator Minchin is really saying is that there was enormous merit in Senator Margetts's move a while ago to have those parts of the bill that we agree on pass through and that the contentious bits be put aside for further consideration as they might be a long time getting through. It would have been sensible, for example, to have allowed the contentious areas to have been looked at by the Joint Standing Committee on Native Title, or even the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee, once there had been areas of general agreement established here. But the government said no to that. Now the government is saying, `And, what's more, we won't entertain any more amendments; and, what's more, we're not really prepared in committee to deal with the 800 or so amendments coming from elsewhere at this stage.'

The government needs to improve its act. The government needs to be far better prepared than that. The government needs to recognise that it has blocked the path to getting the best resolution—the consensus areas of this legislation—through. This has, therefore, led to the Senate in committee having to deal with all these amendments in the next week. For the government to flag up‐front that it has got too hard—that it cannot deal with more amendments, that it is distressed by the fact that the Labor Party, the Greens and the Democrats, and potentially Senator Harradine, have a different point of view and that the government is going to have to analyse that different point of view—is not good enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to participate enormously in the committee stage, because Senator Minchin is more than capable of dealing with most of these matters. But, while the question before the chair is that the bill be agreed to, I should take the opportunity to correct a statement that was made recently and also to put some material before the committee which shows the importance of the bill being agreed to in the form in which it is at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: On Tuesday this week, Mr Fischer, the Deputy Prime Minister, told ABC television that Mr Pearson, the Chairman of the Cape York Land Council, was signatory to an ambit claim over several leasehold properties on Cape York Peninsula. At the time, Mr Fischer was of the belief that these leases were `in transition'—I think that was the phrase used. Mr Pearson denied this and, in an article by Michael Gordon and Georgina Windsor which appeared in yesterday's Australian, Mr Pearson said: `We have deliberately followed a policy of not claiming current pastoral leases in Cape York since 1993.'

I want to correct some misapprehensions about the situation. On 9 October 1997 the Cape York Land Council put out a press release and a media brief relating to a particular claim by the Wuthathi people. In the media brief the Cape York Land Council said, `The claim will be lodged at the National Native Title Tribunal in Brisbane today and covers the occupational licence and pastoral lease in the area.'

I also have a copy of the claim, as lodged with the Native Title Tribunal. It clearly identifies the occupational licence and the lease, and they are current tenures. The pastoral lease in question does not come up for renewal until next year. It is quite ironic that, because the post can be a bit slow from Cape York Peninsula, the leaseholders, Mr and Mrs Nixon, asked me in September to take their application for the renewal of the lease down to the office of the Queensland Minister for Natural Resources in Brisbane. The application was made before this claim was put on the property. The occupational licence is automatically renewed annually, provided that the lessees are using the lease and that the lease is current.

Inquiries this morning with Mr and Mrs Nixon indicate that the lease covers some 49,800 hectares. They mustered over 1,000 head of cattle in August, so they are using the land quite profitably. It is a current operation, and it is incorrect for anybody to form the belief that the Cape York Land Council is following a policy of not claiming pastoral leases. In fact, they made a claim over a pastoral lease on 9 October. It was specifically over this pastoral lease and the occupational licence that was attached. It follows, therefore, that it is very important that the legislation which ensures that these leasehold interests are safe is passed. I will explain why.

It has always been the contention of the Cape York Land Council and Father Frank Brennan that, when a lease comes up for renewal, it is vacant crown land and, therefore, should revert to native title. That is what it is about. Even when the other side were in government they did not share that view.

I put these matters on the record, and I seek the leave of the Senate to table the following documents: the media alert of the Cape York Land Council; the media briefing; the extract from the register of native title claims, accompanied by two maps; the internal historical state tenure search which was attached to that claim; and two newspaper clippings covering the claim itself.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I know Senator Harradine wants to say a few words, but I have to say a couple of things in respect of this. This could be a very long debate if we are going to go into this sort of rhetoric and misinformation around the chamber. We do not need to do that, and it is not the intention of the opposition to run this sort of debate. We will resist provocation.

SPEECH.PARA: All I will do at this stage is also put on the record that when the Cape York Land Council checked the register in respect of the subject areas they found that the register of the state of Queensland showed that each of the leases in the Kalpowar holdings region had been cancelled. They checked it again quite recently, and the searchers confirmed that the area in question was unallocated state land. The description of the land in the application was one made for convenience only. That has been pretty widely promulgated by the Cape York Land Council as well.

In terms of the assertion in respect of seeking exclusive possession, I think it is fair to say that, if one was to look at the claim itself and look at all aspects of the claim, one would see that the claim, in the normal form these claims are made in, included the phrase `save for the valid operation of the laws of the Commonwealth in the state of Queensland'. Therefore, it is accepted by the claimants that native title yields to the rights held by others under valid Australian law.

As I said, we do not need to get into this sort of rhetoric and misinformation. I could talk at length. I do not want to go on at length. I just want to correct the record for this moment. I hope we can move on to a more constructive process of debating.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to see us get on with the amendments that are before us and try to see whether we can deal with them properly and constructively for the rest of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is an excellent thing that all parties have agreed to deal with the four matters—the indigenous land use agreements; the applications claims process and sunset clause; the registration test; and representative bodies—which are probably the least contentious of the matters contained in the legislation. That will give us an opportunity to settle down after the last few days of debate. The debate has been quite good at times but acrimonious sometimes.

I would like to respond to Senator Minchin. I indicate to him, and to other honourable senators, that I will have some amendments. Honourable senators around the chamber will know that there are substantial difficulties in getting amendments up to scratch. The first difficulty is actually being in a position to give drafting instructions. The reason for that is obvious: I was not privy to what the Labor Party was going to do. It eventually made up its mind earlier this week. I received a copy of the draft amendments two days ago, I think.

Obviously, I had to wait until I saw those amendments to decide whether I thought they were entirely satisfactory in terms of my view on this particular matter. Thanks to the National Indigenous Working Group, a week or so ago I had a draft document of the way it was going. That was very useful. Yesterday, I received the final draft of what is being proposed by the group in amendment form.

After consultations yesterday evening, I was able to give drafting instructions. The Senate drafting services of the Procedure Office have been working very late into the night and early this morning on those particular matters. I am most grateful for the resources of this place. We have tremendous resources in the Parliamentary Library. The resources that I have been able to access through the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund have been absolutely excellent. I put that on the record here and now.

For the information of senators, I indicate that I will probably have 21 amendments. As far as today is concerned, I have a mere three or four. Hopefully, they should be circulated in the chamber within the next half‐hour. I have nothing on ILUAs so, if the committee wishes, it can now continue its discussions on that particular subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments that are circulated in the name of the Australian Democrats for the indigenous land use agreements are the same amendments that will be circulated in a new group of slightly amended amendments, which will be under the joint names of the Australian Democrats and the Greens. As can be seen, in most respects they are the same, or virtually identical, to those of the Australian Labor Party. I will be seeking some clarification in relation to opposition amendment No. 44, but I can do that in the course of the debate.
—I would suggest that we are some distance away from opposition amendment No. 44 at this stage.
—I was assuming that we would be debating the packages of amendments cognately, and moving them in bunches; but I am happy to take advice on what is going to be the best way to deal with this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose we are moving to schedule No. 1, and what we have here is government amendments Nos 15 to 18. We then have a batch of opposition amendments, which includes amendment No. 44. I think there are about 20 or even more amendments of the opposition in that batch, and a similar number of Democrat amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: By way of the agreement that we talked about earlier on, Senator Margetts is moving the bundle of Opposition/Democrat/Green amendments on this particular issue. My understanding was that the ones that have been finally settled upon were the opposition amendments, which will be moved. The minor difference between amendments Nos 40 and 44 are such that it will mean that the Democrat amendments will not be moved, but the opposition ones will be. I thought Senator Margetts was going to move those.

To facilitate debate, the idea is that Senator Margetts, or whoever proposes the bundle, speaks to it as a block. What we can get into now, I think, is speaking about the broad area related to ILUAs. If anyone has any particular amendment they want to focus on and analyse, we will obviously go into that process as well. However, the idea was to present them and treat them as a block, and have some capacity to dissect individual ones.

In that respect, I must also say that over the last few days there have been something like six or seven hours of discussions between the government and the opposition where, I suppose, we have had an informal committee stage. A lot of the areas that were of concern, in terms of technical problems and so on, have been clarified. We have not agreed on a lot of things, but we have had the capacity to work some of these issues out. I hope that helps by way of information.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was intending to call the minister so that he could move government amendments Nos 15 to 18, deal with them and then move on to either opposition amendments Nos 16, 23 to 25, 28, 29 and 31 or the associated five Democrat amendments.

—I am suggesting that, given the degree of agreement in respect of all the opposition amendments on the non-government side, we could move all the opposition amendments listed in column 2, including Nos 31 and 256, which I gather that the government will not be supporting. We can move them as a block and not have sequential debates in respect of each area.
—The committee may do as it wishes.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN

TALK.START.PARA: —Before proceeding, I will table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to the bill. The memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 27 November 1997. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (15) Schedule 1, item 9, page 21 (line 11), after "conditions", insert "(which may be about procedural matters)".
(16) Schedule 1, item 9, page 24 (line 24), after "conditions", insert "(which may be about procedural matters)".
(17) Schedule 1, item 9, page 31 (after line 29), at the end of section 24CK, add:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Matters to be taken into account

PARA.TAB: (4) In deciding whether he or she is satisfied as mentioned in paragraph (2)(c), the Registrar must take into account any information given in relation to the matter by:

TAB.TAB: (a) the persons making the objections mentioned in that paragraph; and
(b) the representative Aboriginal/Torres Strait Islander bodies that certified the application;
and may, but need not, take into account any other matter or thing.

SPEECH.PARA: (18) Schedule 1, item 9, page 33 (line 28), after "conditions", insert "(which may be about procedural matters)".

These deal with indigenous land use agreements. It is at least a positive sign that we are starting off the debate with particular amendments in an area where by and large there is certain agreement that the amendment of the act is required and would be of considerable benefit to all land users, most particularly native title holders.

The government believes that the provisions in the bill in relation to indigenous land use agreements have been well thought through, well constructed and properly balanced. There is the need for legal certainty in relation to agreements without unduly requiring or granting to indigenous land councils any monopoly over the process. We think we have struck the right balance in our proposals in relation to the position of native title claimants and holders vis-a-vis land councils. We think it is appropriate that land councils have a role. Having discussed this in great detail with indigenous people, we are reluctant to give land councils anything that might resemble a monopoly.

Amendment No. 15 relates to paragraph 24BB(a), which states that a body corporate agreement may provide for, among other things, the doing of a future act subject to conditions contained in the agreement. This amendment simply makes it clear that these conditions may be about procedural matters. So it is clear that the parties to the agreement can agree to impose procedural requirements in relation to the doing of future acts. We think it is an appropriate and sensible amendment.

No. 16 goes to proposed paragraph 24CB(a). That paragraph states that an area agreement may provide for, amongst other things, the doing of a future act subject to conditions contained in the agreement. Again, it relates to being able to agree on procedural matters. It is obviously a sensible thing that the parties should be able to agree on. There should be no unintentional restriction on it.

Amendment No. 17 goes to proposed section 24CK. That section sets out the conditions for the registration of an area agreement certified by the relevant representative body. The amendment inserts a new subsection (4), which sets out the information to which the registrar must have regard in deciding whether he or she is satisfied, as mentioned in paragraph 24CK(2)(c). The amendment will provide for the registrar to take into account information given by the persons objecting against the registration of the agreement and the representative body that certified the application. The amendment provides that the registrar may, but need not, take into account any other matter or thing. We think that is appropriate. You have to have some objection mechanism to ensure that an agreement is fair and balanced.

Amendment No. 18 goes to proposed paragraph 24DB(a), which provides that an alternative procedure agreement may provide for, amongst other things, the doing of a future act subject to conditions contained in the agreement. This is again to ensure that procedural matters can be included in the agreement. They are technical amendments, but we think they improve the agreements process. Therefore, they should be acceptable to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition does not oppose amendments Nos 15 to 18. We think they do in a minor way add to the measure. As a consequence, we have no problem with them other than to say that we do not think they go far enough. The amendments to be moved by Senator Margetts will fully represent the position of the other parties in this parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to indicate that what the government is presenting by way of amendments Nos 15 to 18 represent minor technical adjustments which we believe will be improved by the amendments I will be moving.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a matter of process—obviously there is no disagreement here—it might be better in the future if we have the debate and then have the votes at the end. I would suggest in the future that we have the votes at the end of the debate on all the relevant amendments in the particular bundle area.

Probably what is happening in the process of our dealing with so many amendments in such a short time is that the amendments under the opposition's name are at the moment in line with the agreements for the compromise of the National Indigenous Working Group.

—When it was first introduced to us, we did say that we would move via the sheets if we could. So it will be amendments Nos 16, 23 to 25, 28, 29, 31, 21, 22, 26, 27, 30, 34, 32, 33, 36, 44, 35, 38, 39, 43, 40 to 42, 45, 46, 47, 48, 193, 196, 194, 195 and 256.
