The indigenous land use agreements provisions in the existing act do not support agreements that will bind all native title holders unless there has been a determination from the court that native title exists and which identifies the group that holds it. Very often, parties can agree on issues such as how the land should be managed—access, compensation, et cetera—but not whether native title exists. It is, therefore, essential that there is a simple means of allowing parties to reach binding agreements without all parties being put to the expense and delay of protracted legal proceedings.

Agreements are voluntary and there will be no compulsion for parties to enter into them. The agreements provide an option to all parties in the event that there is some common ground. The more flexible this process is, having regard to the need to ensure safeguards against abuse, the more likely it is that conflicts can be resolved in a spirit of coexistence rather than the legal equivalent of trench warfare. Part of the problem with putting in a rigid system would be that the nature of the relationship between people through all sectors and the differences between areas cannot be taken into consideration in the way agreements are formed.

It is essential that agreements should be possible without the necessity to lodge a claim. Once the claim process is started, it is actually difficult and expensive for any party to control. Long after the agreement is signed, parties may find that they still have proceedings on foot. The considerations which go into the making of a claim are often more complex, and therefore more time‐consuming and expensive, than reaching an agreement, particularly where the impact on the land of any acts authorised by the agreement are likely to be limited. This is unnecessary and should be avoided.

An agreements process should be flexible enough to deal with small‐scale projects on identified parcels of land; large‐scale projects that may traverse several states, such as a railway or a super highway; agreements that cover minor repeat acts such as road widenings where the right to negotiate may apply, but where more appropriate alternative procedures can be agreed; new native title issues that may emerge as the common law develops, such as rights to marine and mineral resources, without the need to constantly refer the legislation back to the parliament; and validation with proper and full consultation of invalid acts which have either already occurred or which may occur in the future.

We believe that the amendments formulated in conjunction with the National Indigenous Working Group in consultation with the Greens, the Democrats and the Australian Labor Party achieve these objectives. I am happy to mention other particular provisions here. The explanation from the National Indigenous Working Group is that the indigenous land use provisions are largely satisfactory in content as they stand but, to ensure that the indigenous land use agreements can also be used to validate past acts and intermediate acts periods, their scope must be extended and the provisions removed from part 2, division 3 which deals only with future acts.

In the combined amendments there is some tightening up, shining up and improving of the provisions. It has been widely acknowledged that these are legal provisions which will move towards a better outcome for all parties involved. Amendments Nos 21 to 23 and 26 to 28 are consequential amendments on the extension of indigenous land use agreements to cover more than future acts. Amendment 24 relates to registered native title body corporates, which will place upon those bodies an obligation to consult with the relevant representative body prior to entering into an indigenous land use agreement—a similar provision currently exists in the native title regulations. Amendment 29 relates to area agreements, including the same consultation requirement with the relevant representative body as provided in amendment 24. Amendment 35 prevents the registrar from registering an agreement where the relevant representative body has advised that it was not consulted as required, as in amendment 24. Amendment 31 deletes the government's proposed section 24CG(3) and substitutes the requirement that an application for registration must be certified by all relevant representative bodies, that reasonable efforts have been made to identify all affected native title holders, that each of those persons has had a reasonable opportunity to be consulted and that consultation with the relevant representative bodies has occurred.

Amendments 30, 34 and 37 are consequential amendments requiring all area agreements to be certified. Amendments 32, 33, 36 and 44 are consequential on the representative body agreements. Amendment 35 requires the registrar to register an agreement only if the agreement is consistent with any relevant alternative procedure agreement which has previously been registered. Amendments 38 to 43 and 45 and 46 are consequential on the extension of the indigenous land use agreements to cover more than future acts.

Amendment 47 promotes the use of indigenous land use agreements to signify the primary role it is hoped that they will play in the resolution of native title issues. This amendment relocates the provision relating to indigenous land use agreements to the front of the act. This will also ensure that the provisions apply to the resolution of native title issues generally and not just for future acts. Amendment 48 inserts a title and overview of the division relating to indigenous land use agreements. I commend the amendments to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments moved by Senator Margetts are co‐sponsored by the Democrats and others on behalf of the National Indigenous Working Group. The Democrats believe that the government has missed entirely the essence of what native title can be. We believe at its heart that native title is about including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the future of the nation. Let us be quite clear about this. Until the Mabo decision, the only way indigenous people were included was through acts of paternalism and a welfare mentality. I do not think I will repeat the history of the Queensland government that I gave the other night, but, if ever there is an example of that or if ever you want any illustration of it, I can always do that again.

SPEECH.PARA: The indigenous land use agreements give us the opportunity to put that past of paternalism and sometimes outright racism behind us. No area of contention or conflict in human society is ever in the long term worked out by endless recourse to the courts, nor is it worked out by having the rights of some people put asunder to those who have more power, more money and more clout. That is not what living in a civilised and humane society which is respectful of difference and celebratory of diversity and multiculturalism is about. The amendments to the indigenous land use agreements facilitate an improvement of the regime and an encouragement for all stock holders to sit down and coexist, share and reconcile with indigenous Australia. The Australian Democrats will be supporting these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —While the government has given serious consideration to these amendments, we believe on balance that with the structure we have formulated, taking careful consideration of the propositions put to us by the Indigenous Working Group and ATSIC and other Aboriginal interests, we are not on balance able to accept these opposition and Democrat amendments. The first block of amendments really relates to extending the cover of indigenous land use agreements to acts occurring before the Wik decision on 23 December 1996. In other words, they seek to extend the scope of these agreements beyond future acts.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not think that that is at all appropriate because past acts, that is, acts that occurred prior to the commencement of the Native Title Act on 1 January 1994, have all been validated by the 1993 act and the current ILUA provisions are already wide enough to cover agreements about compensation for those acts. The concept of validation of intermediate period acts by agreement is not acceptable to us. Essentially, it means that validation can only occur by agreement and, if that is the case, then effectively it leaves a veto. I do not want to be accused of abusing the term `veto' but, obviously, if something cannot occur unless there is agreement then, by definition, if there is no agreement it cannot occur and that means that the party to the agreement has a veto. In this case, what you are saying is that, if the relevant native title parties do not agree, they have a veto over validation and to leave that validity question entirely dependent on that agreement is simply unacceptable.

The next block of amendments—24, 25, 30, 34, 37 and 31—go to the question of certification of area agreements. Effectively, they require that area agreements have to be certified by representative bodies and touch on the obligation to consult representative bodies. Whatever you may say, Senator Margetts, I certainly have spent much of the last 20 months travelling Australia talking to a range of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander groups and communities and one thing that you become very conscious of is that the position of land councils—and they are representative bodies—is a controversial one within Aboriginal communities. I have heard more invective directed towards land councils from Aboriginal people than from any other Australians.

In our total bill, we are seeking to give representative bodies a critical role in the process. We do generally support—and I think you would accept that our amendments do enhance—the role of representative bodies in ways recommended by the report which the previous government commissioned. but based on the judgment we formed after discussions with a whole range of Aboriginal interests, we do not believe we should do anything to give a monopoly in relation to agreements to representative bodies.

We do believe that, as a result of our amendments, native title holders will be encouraged to use the services of representative bodies, and that is what they are there for. We believe in funding them well, in establishing them well and making them accountable, democratic and representative to ensure that they can provide a very profes sional service to native title holders. I do not wish to be disrespectful, but the National Indigenous Working Group is basically made up of land councils and they would have a vested interest, obviously, in seeking to acquire such a monopoly.

What matters here is the native title holders themselves, and they are not necessarily, by definition, going to have exactly the same interests as a representative body. It is fine to have the representative bodies well serviced, as I say, and well funded to provide a facilitating role, a professional service, for native title holders but, at the end of the day, native title holders, in our view, should retain the capacity to choose to deal directly with other parties in reaching agreements rather than be forced to do so through a representative body.

We have facilitated and encouraged, as I say, the use of representative bodies but, at the end of the day, the content of agreements should be a matter for the parties. Representative bodies are there to assist native title holders, not to determine the contents of agreements. So we are, therefore, not able to accept those amendments, although I appreciate the intention.

We are not satisfied that amendment No. 35—registration of area agreements only if consistent with alternative procedure agreement—is absolutely necessary. We would presume the parties to the area agreement would be bound to act consistently with the provisions in any event. So, on balance, we are not clear that is a necessary amendment. Amendments Nos 32, 33, 36 and 44 relate to the issue of representative body transitionals and, based on our view on that issue, we cannot accept these amendments because we do not accept the premise on which they are based.

Opposition amendments Nos 47, 48, 193 and 196 really bring about a move of the ILUA provisions in a positional sense in the bill to put them before the future act regime, and that relates to the proposition that ILUAs cover the validation of past and immediate acts. Therefore, it is inconsistent with our restructuring of the act under our amendments to bring all provisions relating to future acts into the same division so that it is much clearer and easier to understand how the bill is working. As I say, our whole premise is that agreements relate to the doing of future acts.

Finally, amendments Nos 194 and 195 are about the removal from the register of agreements, and our legal advice is that what is proposed here does have some problems. It is not clear to us what qualification, if any, the proposed subsection 199C(4) would put on the concept already in 199C(3) of `being induced to enter into the agreement by reasons of fraud, undue influence or duress'. As a matter of law, fraud or duress do negate any agreement since they render consent to the agreement invalid. If the proposed subsection had the effect of allowing some improperly induced agreements to stand, that would clearly be a departure from general legal principles applying to contract agreements.

This amendment is a limitation on the capacity of the Federal Court to remove an agreement from the register if persons who are later determined to hold native title would not have authorised the agreement. Therefore, on balance, and given the legal advice on the operation of this, we are not able to accept it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just respond to some of the points. It is a bit unfortunate that Senator Minchin has not been able to accept some of these amendments because we think that they are important and would facilitate what, I suppose, Wik was all about. Wik was all about coexistence. The best way to ensure coexistence is by agreement, and the best way to do that is to apply a capacity to have agreements in the act to as wide a range as possible. So when Senator Minchin says that he wants them to apply only to a certain range, not to other areas as we recommend—the intermediate act regime and also past acts—it is unfortunate that he has not seen fit to embrace these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Those who might have been anticipating a bit of fireworks this morning will be disappointed. We are actually already into what one journalist this morning called `the driest mechanical exercise in law making', and I think that is why we have got right into it very quickly. I thank David Marr for that comment. We are into some technical points, but the technical points have some important ramifications.

The best way to apply ILUAs is to ensure that they can have as wide a scope as possible. Let us face it: agreements at the appropriate time and as early as possible have enormous benefits, benefits that you cannot buy through a court process or a tribunal process. They not only provide certainty but also can define very early in the piece the relationship between the parties and can engender a great degree of goodwill that you would not get out of a court process. They provide a framework. They provide an ongoing good relationship. They can define roles. They can allow people to control the outcome without having to spend enormous resources. To that extent, we are very keen to ensure that they can be used as widely as possible.

Senator Minchin said that, if we were to apply them to be available to validate past acts or intermediate acts, it would ensure that the claimants would have a right of veto. That is a misunderstanding of the position that we are putting up. The position that we are putting up is that a capacity to use the ILUA provisions of the bill should be made as an alternative to whatever this parliament decides on as the validating regime. We are not saying it has to go down the agreement route. It is an alternative that is available to parties. It could very well be available to and used by parties quite beneficially if they had the capacity to pursue the agreement route as opposed to the form of validation route that this parliament might finally decide on.

Let us make it available to them. There is no downside to that. Parties do not have to use it, but parties in their good sense may actually see that to ensure that issues do not continue to fester, to ensure that the common law is not utilised, they could actually have this route available. I suggest to Senator Minchin that he may have some misunderstanding of what we are trying to do here. We are not prescribing it for all occasions; we are making it available as an alternative.

In terms of the area agreement argument, you have concerns with rep bodies having a role and you say there is community concern about rep bodies, but your own bill recognises the importance of them and the vital role that rep bodies can play in the process. For instance, clause 24CK of the bill provides for certification of agreements by rep bodies. You acknowledge their role there. Clause 24CL(3) and 24CL(4) of the bill require the registrar to consider any information relating to the identity and authority of native title holders provided by a rep body in the registration process.

So let us face it: the rep bodies are important in the process. What we say is why allow them a role later down the track, when to put them in the play earlier in the development of area agreements could be quite fundamental to a cohesive outcome? We have to also take into account the people we are talking about here. Let us acknowledge that there is a massive imbalance between individual or small groups of indigenous Australians and the people they are negotiating with, who have big resources, access to lawyers, access to accountants and access to all sorts of facilities. It is important for those individual indigenous Australians to be able to have access to advice. Obviously, if they had the resources, they could go out and buy legal advice, but if they do not the rep bodies could quite validly provide for them.

We are not talking about continuation of the rep bodies as they currently exist in some areas, because we are all agreed on reforms to the rep body process and we will come to that later. But it is important for equity reasons that rep bodies have the capacity to play a role in the formulation of area agreements and protecting native title claimants but also assisting the process. The government acknowledges their importance in some areas. Let us take a real equitable approach to this and ensure that they do have a capacity to play a role in respect of area agreements as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —As was mentioned by Senator Bolkus, there is an option in relation to the use of indigenous land use agreements—and they are called agreements. There is really no point in having a situation where one group or individuals can be picked off, if you like, by those people who have the corporate expertise, legal advice and so on, so other people feel they are forced into an agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an option. It is something that is favoured by many groups and it is not unreasonable to suggest it should actually be an agreement. It should be a consensual agreement. That does mean leaving people with the ability to get together and form something that everybody is happy with. I do not think that is so onerous and I do not think it would be considered inappropriate in business. I really do not know why it is considered by Senator Minchin or the government to be inappropriate in relation to what is supposed to be not only something that gets ticked off and signed off but something that all parties can work with and continue to work with.

So it is absolutely important that that is a consensual agreement process. Yes, it is true that, if somebody is not happy, that part of the agreement will not be registered. But what is the point of having people who continue to be unhappy signing on to something? It is supposed to be the safety valve in this whole process, to avoid the unhappiness or legal battles that can be avoided. I really do think the consensual approach is the only sensible and reasonable approach to take.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear that at the end of the day there will be validating provisions in respect of intermediate period acts. Obviously, the opposition is supporting a form of validation and it is in the legislation here. I would ask the minister and perhaps Senator Margetts how they would see the validation and the use of ILUAs for that particular purpose operating side by side. Senator Bolkus has indicated that the intention of the measures that are now before us is that ILUAs be utilised as alternatives to the validation procedures that are being proposed by both the government and the opposition. I just wanted to hear from the minister and Senator Margetts how in practice this would work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my opinion that they do work together. Yes, they are an alternative to each other and they do work together, so I would think there should not be a problem there.

SPEECH.PARA: I would just like to add one issue I forgot to mention in relation to Senator Minchin saying that they are in favour of well‐resourced rep bodies. I am not sure I would agree that rep bodies are necessarily well resourced. There are some which are well resourced and some which are not. There are also corporations which are in the process of trying to manage land rights claims which have very few resources at all, and there are all sorts of reasons for that, including inadequate funding for ATSIC. So the minister might blandly say that they are well resourced, but there are many people out in the bush who know the reality is quite different.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I could speak for a long time on this particular issue, but we are going to come to the issue of rep bodies later. One of the problems for representative bodies has been the lack of resources. That is one of the reasons why the problems have arisen. Of course, native title holders, individual Aboriginal people and ATSIC at different times have got quite angry about representative bodies. One reason for that—not the only reason, but one of the reasons—is that the lack of resources has meant the representative bodies have not been able to fulfil the functions that are expected of them. That is one of the fundamental reasons why we have had problems with representative bodies.

SPEECH.PARA: What these amendments are trying to do is make indigenous land use agreements really work to give people alternatives. If we do not do this, we will have problems, and let me tell you about some of the problems which are already arising. A problem they are having in many areas is between those who are now termed traditional people and those who are termed historical people—particularly in Queensland.

I will just give you some examples. For instance, there are people who live at Mapoon who can trace back their ancestry for many generations—they are the traditional people. However, there are also people who were brought there. Perhaps their parents, grand parents or great‐grandparents were transferred from other communities and dumped in Mapoon.

This was a policy for many years of different Queensland governments. What happened, of course, was that after two or three generations of living there, these people regarded themselves as residents and as people from Mapoon. There is a conflict between these people, who may only have two or three generations of residency, and the traditional people who have many generations of residency in Mapoon.

The Cape York Land Council has had great difficulty in sorting out the claims of those two groups of Aboriginal people. What we are saying is that we have to give maximum flexibility, in terms of indigenous land use agreements, so that not only conflicts between pastoralists or miners and Aboriginal people but also conflicts between different native title claimants can be resolved.

What these amendments would do is give the possibility of maximum flexibility. I could talk about many other communities where the same problem has surfaced in different ways. I would certainly add my appeal to that of Senator Bolkus and Senator Margetts that the government support these propositions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question for the minister. As I understand it, there is an objection to the area over which agreements might operate. Can the minister tell us in what other areas of the law there is a prohibition against settlements of a dispute operating, as long as what is being settled is lawful and adults are involved?

—I also have a question for the minister while he is on his feet. I heard what Senator Margetts said about the ILUAs operating in tandem with the validation provisions, but, of course, I am aware also of what is being proposed in respect of the latter by the Greens and the Democrats. The validation question is neither—to put it mildly—entirely in line with the bill nor in line with the opposition amendments relating to that. The question in my mind, which will need to be answered by the minister, is whether or not the ILUAs are able to operate instead of, or in association with, the validation procedures. Senator Bolkus might respond so far as his amendments on validation procedures are concerned. I hope that the minister will also respond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I can answer that question from my perspective while the minister formulates his response. We actually see that these ILUA provisions can sit with whatever validation provisions get through the Senate, whether it is the government's or the opposition's. They are provided as an alternative. With respect to validated acts, you could say, `Where would having this capacity be of any use if, for instance, the government's provisions got through or even if the opposition's provisions got through?'

SPEECH.PARA: We see it as an opportunity, an avenue that is available. It is not enforced in any way. It is an alternative that is available to people. There will obviously be disputes in any validation regime. Those disputes can be handled either under the act or through the common law. We say that we should also make available to claimants and parties to any dispute a capacity to use the agreements provisions as well, if they so seek, to provide extra certainty.

From our perspective, there is no good reason as to why you should not make this provision available in the interests of certainty, no matter what regime you pick up. As we have seen more and more in recent weeks, parties are coming to regional agreements, area agreements and site specific agreements. I think you will probably find that the practice of some industry sectors is to go down this road rather than go down the road which may give some immediate satisfaction but may not give the longer term certainty that they need. That is why we say we should make it available and then the parties have a choice whether they pick it up. It will not, in any way, impinge on any aspect of either our validation regime or the government's.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that, given the scope and depth of our amendments in relation to agreements, the parliament would accept our bona fides in strongly supporting the agreements process. In relation to rep bodies, we have given them a substantial role in the process without the ultimate power of monopoly. In relation to resources, the federal government, through ATSIC, is funding representative bodies around the country to the tune of $40 million per annum—that is an increase from $25 million when the act first came into effect. Forty million dollars is, in my terms, a sizeable amount of money. Obviously, every organisation in Australia would like more money, but $40 million is not a small sum.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we should make clear the more substantive question that has been raised about agreements. Obviously, in general terms, agreements relate to the doing of future acts. Let us agree on who can do what, when, where and under what conditions. That is the whole point of an agreements mechanism. The agreements mechanism in the act is designed to give parties the option to come to agreements about the doing of future acts on land on which native title may have survived, without going through all the other future act processes of the Native Title Act. They can agree among themselves to the way in which the future act shall be done and then ensure, by that agreement being registered, that the future act is valid. Otherwise you have to go through all the future act regime, and that is one of the deficiencies of the current act. That is obviously a good thing, and we all agree on that.

In response to Senator Cooney, there is nothing to stop parties agreeing, either under this act or by a common law agreement, on the doing of anything in relation to past acts—past acts being some sort of tenement that has been issued in the past—and parties then agreeing as to how future activity in relation to that past act is conducted. We do not and cannot accept a proposition that the validity of a past act can be dependent upon an agreement. This may be a point of departure, but it is one in which we feel quite strongly. We do think it is essential for legal certainty.

In respect of the parties being issued with tenements and leases in good faith—having, in many cases, probably invested millions of dollars and employed hundreds of people in these projects—legal certainty must be granted by way of a validation regime, as the parliament validated everything done prior to the commencement of the Native Title Act. So in the circumstances, but in a more limited way, our validation regime will provide for the validation of acts that occurred on pastoral leases in that 1994 to 1996 period. So they have to be validated.

Parties can subsequently come to agreement about the doing of things in relation to those validated past acts. There is absolutely nothing in our agreements mechanism which prevents that at all. All we are saying is that there is no need to amend our amendments or accept these amendments proposed by the other parties to enable that to occur. We are simply not going to support any proposition that some past acts will have their validation dependent upon agreement being reached, because that is to say that, if agreement is not reached, the act remains invalid. That is simply not acceptable to the government.

So I hope I have made clear what we are coming to. I guess it does flow from perhaps some differences of opinion about the scope of the validation regime. If you accept, rightly or wrongly, that these titles were issued in good faith by governments that had a clear understanding of the law in relation to the status of pastoral leases—and, whether we like it or not, those have all been issued and investments have been made in relation to them and people have been employed—we think the validation is essential. Therefore, the agreements provisions can operate and can deal with anything that the parties want to agree with in relation to those validated acts, but we cannot accept any proposition that validation itself is subject to, or dependent upon, agreement.

SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, with respect, there is some confusion here about past acts and future acts. TALK.START.PARA: —The other provisions of the act have an ongoing timetable and schedule and deadlines that people have to meet, but, by pursuing the ILUA avenue in respect of future acts, the other processes are not precluded from operating, are they?

TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

SPEECH.PARA: Our point was, and I state it again, in relation to indigenous land use agreements and their legal effect, we are saying that we cannot accept amendments that are premised on the basis that there will not be a full validation of intermediate past acts. The presumption in your amendments is that there will not be a full validation regime so, if you accept the premise that there is a full validation regime, your amendments contradict that proposition.

BREAK.PARA: Your amendments are founded on a proposition with which we cannot agree. Agreements are about giving legal validity to the doing of certain things that otherwise would be invalid and otherwise have to go through the future act regime. If you validate past acts, they are valid, and there is no question of an agreement being necessary to ensure their validity. It does not mean that the parties cannot come to agreements, either inside or outside the act, about matters relating to the exercise of rights under the validated act. There is nothing in our amendments which prevent that occurring at all. I think that may be where the misunderstanding is. So the agreements can fully operate in relation to those validated past acts.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legal impact of our amendments extending the operation of ILUAs to cover intermediate period acts and past acts is whether the legal impact would be of an effect that would impinge on the validation regime, whether or not it is the one in the bill. TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, Madam Chair, we are debating something that has already been voted on. I cannot see the point of continuing to debate it. The Senate has made a decision in relation to these amendments and we should now proceed to conclude this section by item 37.

SPEECH.PARA: Our point was that our agreements regime is entirely comprehensive and is essentially designed, of course, to deal with future acts, but the whole provision is premised on the basis that agreements can be reached about the doing of past acts that have been validated. That is what I am saying: your amendments are only there because you are not intending to provide, in our view, a proper validation regime, and therefore we cannot accept them. As I said, we are debating something we have already voted on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not doing that because we still have before us the question of area agreements, and ILUAs can be seen to be quite relevant in respect of those, so I do not think we have fully concluded the discussion about the extension of ILUAs to cover intermediate period and past acts.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I want to clarify, which I do not think Senator Minchin has yet answered, is what the legal impact of extending the capacity this bill provides for the use of ILUAs to cover intermediate period and past acts is. Would an extension of this access to ILUAs impinge in any way on any validation regime that goes through this House? My contention is that it would not. Whether Senator Minchin's validation regime or the opposition's validation regime goes through this House, that regime will provide the degree of certainty the parliament finally decides in respect of a regime that will be, in a sense, compulsory.

Putting aside the metaphysics about whether something can sit easily with something else, my contention also is that making available the use of ILUAs, as is provided by this legislation, would in no way impinge on that validation regime that passes this parliament. The reason we still pursue it is that we still think that having access to those ILUA provisions can provide for parties that come to an agreement a very ready recourse which will be beneficial for all concerned in respect of being able to give effect to those ILUAs under the act.

My concern is that the parliament has not been given correct advice about the impact of the opposition's amendments in regard to ILUAs. My concern is that the parliament was misled, to the effect that, if we were to adopt provisions that extended the capacity to use ILUAs, as proposed, then somehow the legal effect of that would be to undermine the validation regime passed by this parliament. That is why we continue to raise this. We are still talking about area agreements, and that is still a live issue, if we want to contain the debate to that.

But I want to establish clearly, for the sake of the record that, were we to adopt an extension of ILUAs to cover intermediate period acts and past acts, such an extension would not have any legal impact at all and would in no way undermine your validation regime, if that were to get through, or ours, if that were to get through. If none got through, that would be another thing. But explain in what way adoption of that extension would have legal impact on your validation regime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I am repeating myself again. Your amendments are only necessary because you are not prepared to ensure the validation of all intermediate past acts that need to be validated. What you are really saying is that, without this, there is a problem with the validation regime.

SPEECH.PARA: We regard the provision as utterly unnecessary. Agreements can be reached about anything to do with a validated past act. There is nothing in our agreements that prevents that occurring, so I reject the accusation that I have somehow misled you or the parliament. That is nonsense. What we are saying is that there is nothing in our amendments that prevents agreements being reached in relation to the doing of things that are triggered by or necessitated by or that players wish to agree about in relation to validated past acts. But, to the extent that you are later going to propose that validation is much more limited than we believe is absolutely necessary to ensure legal certainty, we oppose your amendments. It has been voted on, and we are going over old ground.

Because it has to be procedurally taken out and dealt with separately, the next subject is amendment 37 to delete the certification area—registration of agreements not certified by rep bodies. That is an amendment to delete that section. That is consequential and, therefore, we oppose it, because it is consequential on an amendment that previously was lost. We are now dealing with this consequential amendment 37, which we oppose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has still refused to confirm that there would be any legal impact. I do understand why you are doing that, because there will not be any legal impact. There will not in any way be any legal undermining of either the government's or the opposition's validation regime. You know that extremely well. You also know that ILUAs do not only have to deal with validation. They can deal with compensation issues as well, after validation. That is why we think it is also important to be able to apply ILUAs under this act to cover past acts and intermediate period acts as well.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern is that we have been misled. You say people can also go off and agree about whatever they want to agree about. In practice that is right. But your act provides under 24BB on page 21 that indigenous land use agreements, ILUAs, under this act must be about one or more of the following matters in relation to an area:
(a) the doing, or the doing subject to conditions, of particular future acts, or future acts included in classes;

You are limiting it to future acts. We are saying that ILUAs registrable under this bill, with force under this bill, can also have a very useful role to play with respect to past acts and intermediate period acts. We say that because they can provide not just a compensation regime but they can provide a very healthy alternative to a validation regime which people may want to contest, and they could contest it at common law. The bottom line is that, were we to extend the capacity for ILUAs under this act to include intermediate period acts and past acts, there would be no legal undermining of your validation regime or ours. I would like you to acknowledge that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

You also seem to be unaware that our agreement provisions clearly contemplate and allow for agreements about compensation in relation to past validated acts. So our agreement provisions are comprehensive and complete. We are not going to fall for the problem that the previous government did in 1993 where you had an act which you rendered full of clauses with unintended consequences. We believe, as the Senate has now already voted, that the agreements provisions are comprehensive and complete and enable the doing of agreements in relation to future acts and in relation to anything to do with past acts that have been validated as well as compensation. For the benefit of Senator Harradine, if I can just summarise briefly—

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard you.

—Okay, I do not have to summarise briefly. In that context we could probably move on to the next vote, but I do indicate that at the first available opportunity we will be putting these amendments. Given what Senator Minchin said before lunch, I do not think he would oppose them but obviously he would like to see how they are worded.

—The committee would be assisted if, while we are waiting on that, we put the question that schedule 1, item 9 of proposed section 24CL stand as printed. That is opposition amendment No. 37 on the first sheet.
—I do not know to what extent we need any more debate on this. I do not know whether Senator Harradine wants us to go through the arguments again.
—They are consequential on the previous vote.
—Yes. Is everyone clear on what we are voting on?

—I might raise this point. It may be best to leave this particular provision until we determine the most recently signalled opposition amendments. We are talking here about covering area agreements. If our next set of amendments get up—they reflect what you said before lunch was the state of the law—it probably will be important to allow rep bodies to have a role in the formulation of the area agreements.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite obviously, whether or not our next set of amendments gets up, the question of area agreements is something which can be treated as being quite separate from the question of whether ILUAs can be extended to cover intermediate period and past acts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

Schedule 1, item 9 of proposed section 24CL should stand as printed because it provides for procedures that need to be followed for the registration of area agreements not certified by representative bodies, as I explained in our previous debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst we are just having another look at that, I indicate that the further opposition amendments with respect to indigenous land use agreements are in fact being circulated and have been given to the government. —Excuse me, Senator Bolkus. I believe something has been circulated, but it is not that amendment. I believe the one circulated is not the one you are now speaking to.
—I have been circulated with—if I can use those words—the other one as well.

—I ask a question while Senator Bolkus is working it out. Proposed subsection 24CL(4)(b) states that the Registrar can take into account any information the Registrar is given on the matter by any representative Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander body or by any other body or person. Does that mean literally any other body or person? If so, how could the Registrar with equity, if you like, reject an application without giving the applicant a chance to be heard? If that is the approach that is taken, don't you then have in effect a full-scale hearing taking place? I am just wondering what is the point of having 24CL(4)(b) in there at all. If you accept the application, then you are going to accept it anyhow. But, if you reject it, you have to have a full‐scale hearing and you might be almost having a judicial hearing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are going to some lengths to ensure that where an area agreement is not certified by a rep body all relevant matters are taken into account. We are putting in safety provisions in other words. We are saying that we do not want to give rep bodies a monopoly on this but, where there is no certification by the rep body, then a number of conditions must be met to ensure a proper agreement has been reached.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, we are simply saying in (4) that the registrar must take into account both the statements in the application and any information the registrar is given on the matter by the rep body. So we are acknowledging that the rep body can have a role in this process but not one of monopoly. So she is required to take account of whatever information the rep body wishes to give her—or any other body or person—in deciding whether she is going to register an area agreement that is not certified by the rep body. So we are putting in safety mechanisms in relation to those agreements where there is no certification.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that that was an administrative act in registering the thing. The bill says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . any information the Registrar is given . . . by any other body or person;

That seems to endanger the administrative nature of your act, unless you are simply going to say, `We are going to take into account this information, not give the applicant any full hearing on the matter and just dismiss it.' If you do that, that would seem to be not giving a fair and proper hearing to it. If you do get a fair and proper hearing to it, you are in effect conducting the case in any event. What I am wanting to get from you is how high a risk you think there is of the administrative act becoming a judicial one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do regard it as an administrative matter as to whether an agreement is to be registered and therefore take legal effect. The words are self‐evident. The registrar must take account of these matters in the administration of the registration process. I do not really see that it is going to lead to a judicial hearing or could lead to the action being judicial. It is an administrative matter as to the registration of agreement. Legal consequences flow from the registration, but in administering the registration process the act sets down what the registrar must take account of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —It says:

SPEECH.PARA: If the conditions are not satisfied, the Registrar must not register the agreement.

So it flows from that that the matters that the registrar takes into account can lead to a dismissal of the agreement. And it can be a dismissal on the evidence provided by bodies and persons other than the applicant. If the registrar is going to taken into account evidence given by other bodies or persons without giving it due weight, haven't you in effect got a negative result where the person is thrown out, the claimant is thrown out, on a basis of hearing evidence other than that which he himself provides? If you are going to treat that evidence properly and give the applicant a chance to respond, haven't you in effect got a judicial hearing? The present situation, as I understand it, is that the applicant provides evidence and makes out a prima facie case on his own evidence ex parte. Here it is not an ex parte application any more; it is a full‐fledged hearing. If it is full‐fledged hearing, it becomes a judicial function with judicial consequences in the fact that his claim is finished.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

—I think we are persuaded by the government's arguments with respect to the consequential or otherwise nature of the provision that we were just discussing. I wonder at this stage whether the government has had a chance to look at the amendments that we have circulated with respect to 24BB(f).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to these amendments we just got, they are an absolutely redundant and unnecessary provision. This is not required in order for 24BB to operate fully and effectively. SPEECH.PARA: Certain members of the opposition have been saying this bill is too big and too long and too complex. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Before lunch Senator Minchin said it was his view that 24BB(a) had a capacity to include intermediate period acts and past acts. That is what he said before lunch. Our concern is that 24BB(a)—and I think it is a very strong concern—could be read down to mean that an ILUA can involve any other matter concerning native title rights as is provided in (f) but only in relation to future acts or future acts included in classes. What we are talking about here is adding six words to 24BB(f) to make sure that what the minister has said would have effect. The minister just said once again that he has no problem with what we are trying to do but he does not want to cloud up his 342 page act with six extra words.

SPEECH.PARA: Come on! It is just six words there, six words with respect to page 25 and six words with respect to page 34 and you have all the certainty you want. Otherwise, given what you have said in parliament today and given what you have said in clarifying the provisions of the bill, what you have said could be used in a court of law and could form the basis of anyone trying to argue that indigenous land use agreements under this act can cover past acts and intermediate period acts. What I am saying to you is, if what you have told this parliament is right, you should have no problem in adding the six extra words in this particular clause. I would suggest that, in the interests of pushing this debate forward, it would be an easy thing to do so we can proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are entirely satisfied with the operation of 24BB(f). I do not understand the legal presumptions upon which Senator Bolkus is operating. Clause 24BB says `The agreement must be about one or more of the following matters in relation to an area,' and then it lists (a) to (f) which have equal status. The agreement can be about any one of those matters or all of them or any number of them. So the agreement can be about `any other matter concerning native title rights and interests in relation to the area'. Whatever the area is and whatever acts have occurred there in the past, the agreement can cover any matter concerning native title rights and interests in relation to the area. That is quite clear and obvious and makes it clear that an agreement can be reached solely about that.

SPEECH.PARA: I continue to say that I just cannot see what purpose is served by your additional words. They are not necessary. Subclause (f) covers the matters you would wish to cover and certainly covers the doing of any matter concerning native title rights and interests in relation to an area where a past act has occurred. Therefore, we are not prepared to accept it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about clause 24BB which will go into the future acts regime of the legislation. Your advisers know this; you know this. The context of what we are talking about is amending the futures acts provision. We are talking about 24BB itself and subclause (a) relating to future acts or future acts included in classes. We are talking about future acts going into a future acts provision of the Native Title Act. In those circumstances, it is quite fair of us to say that, if you think that (f) encompasses a capacity to have ILUAs in respect of past acts and intermediate period acts and to ensure that there is no uncertainty, you need to put those words in. Otherwise, any court confronted with this problem—and your advisers know this, and you should—would look at the colour of the context in which this provision is going to go in. They will see it is in respect of the future acts regime. They will see that subclause (a) relates to future acts. There is a very big chance they would read it down, contrary to what you have told this parliament they do.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry, Minister. Those words need to go in to ensure certainty and to ensure a reflection of what you have told this parliament. I am not prepared to take it on trust because I think it is fair to say that it would be very arguable in any court of law that what you have said here today may not stand up. It is for that reason I am going to force this to a vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had a good look at 24BB, `Coverage of body corporate agreements'. I listened carefully before lunch to what was being said in the committee. I heard the arguments that were being advanced with regard to the Greens‐Democrats amendments supported by the opposition and voted accordingly. With respect, I also did hear the minister indicate his concern about those provisions because they are based on the presumption that the full validation regime may not be implemented, and I accepted that. During that contribution I had for one reason or another believed that if we as a committee—not only me but another 35 or 36 people, however many there were—decided the issue on the basis of those facts, that is, if we were not to oppose those amendments, there would be considerable uncertainty.

SPEECH.PARA: In the debate, I was under the impression that the ALUAs could be utilised for the purposes of considering issues such as compensation and other types of issues in respect of the acts that are going to be validated, namely, the intermediate period acts which will then be, as we all know, as defined in colloquial terms, past acts. Under those circumstances, I feel obliged to vote for the amendments that are being put forward by Senator Bolkus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite clear on the face of it that agreements can be made about compensation in relation to validated past acts. Agreements can be reached about compensation because that is matters flowing from it, but into the future. Paragraph (f) is quite wide and gives great scope for agreements, but what the ALP is on about is having a mechanism by which it can ensure that it does not provide a full validation regime. That is what you are on about. This is a very naked exercise in ensuring that you do not provide a full validation regime. That is why you are trying to put these words in.

SPEECH.PARA: You are not prepared to ensure the validation of intermediate period past acts. Those acts should be validated, they are validated under our bill and, therefore, anything that is done in relation to the parties involved in anything that flows from acts being not acts on the ground but the issue of mining leases and things like that, which have occurred in the intermediate period, is validated. If parties wish to reach agreement about things that flow from that act as a legal device, they can be entered into under these provisions as they stand. These words are utterly redundant and unnecessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I will let it go to the keeper, but we are serious about a validating regime, and Senator Minchin knows it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Woodley, would you like to pursue amendment No. 40?
—No, we will not be proceeding with No. 40. It was caught up in No. 44.
—Do you wish to pursue Democrat amendment No. 32?
—No.
—What has happened to 37?
—We were persuaded that it was consequential to the batch of amendments that were lost, so it would be meaningless to proceed with our opposition to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (60) Schedule 2, item 19, page 148 (line 9), after "waters", insert "(including any activities in exercise of those rights and interests)".

The amendment requires the applicants to include details of any activities relating to the exercise of native title rights and interests when they are providing details of the rights and interests covered by the application. We think that is an unexceptionable amendment. It will assist in the mediation of claims if the claimants make clear in their application matters relating to the exercise of those native title rights. That will considerably facilitate mediation of claims.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it possible to go back to amendment No. 33?
—We have dealt with that.
—May I seek leave to return to consideration of amendment No. 33?
—We are part way through government amendment No. 60, so we will deal with this particular amendment and then you can seek leave to return to amendment No. 33, Senator Margetts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of opposition amendments to this area which can generally be called applications, and they go to the application process. I would like to speak to them as a batch. They appear on the running sheet. There are seven or eight of them. I indicate at this stage that we will not be proceeding with circulated amendment No. 243. A bit of duplication is involved and so we do not need to proceed with that.

SPEECH.PARA: We are concerned about workability. That has been one of our driving forces in producing the 350 or so amendments on this side of the parliament. Workability has a number of different dimensions. One of them is to see what sort of process we can develop and how flexible that process can be to ensure positive and agreed outcomes in one sense, and ready and quick outcomes in another.

The particular background to this area goes to the Brandy decision, which has necessitated quite a number of amendments to the structure of the tribunal and the court in its interaction with respect to native title applications. It is for that reason that we accepted the amendments circulated and moved by Senator Minchin in amendment block 16. We are concerned that in the bill itself the government has in many ways overreached what we think was necessary for it to enact and has gone too far in a way that impinges not just on people's basic rights but also on a fair process.

In short, the government is doing a number of things. Formerly, for instance, all applica tions were commenced in the tribunal. Under the amendment we just picked up, applications are to commence in the Federal Court, where any opposing party may bring an application to strike them down. But much of the work will still be conducted in the tribunal.

The strike‐out provisions in the act allow the court to strike out applications which do not meet the necessary application requirements—this is in proposed section 61—or if any of the areas of the application have been the subject of a previous exclusion possession act, or the applicant claims exclusive possession over an area covered by a previous non-exclusive possession act, or a native title determination has already been made for an area. The application may also be struck down if required documents and information which accompany the application are not provided—this is in proposed section 62—and the court is required to consider the strike‐out application before the application can proceed.

There are also requirements as to information and material. The application must contain, amongst other things, results and copies of searches carried out to determine any non-native title interests in the area. A description of the native title interests and rights claimed must be supplied along with a general description and the factual basis on which the claim is asserted. Details of any activities currently carried on in relation to the land by the claimant group are also implied, as are the details of any other applications to the courts or a recognised state or territory body.

We have some criticisms of the government's position. It is worth putting them on record here, because we will be handling quite of few of them in this part of the debate. Following the Brandy decision, there is consensus as to the role of the Federal Court and the tribunal. As I said earlier, we think the provisions unnecessarily overreach in a number of different ways. In terms of the process itself, a claim cannot be registered if the application covers an area which has at any time in the past or present been covered by a previous exclusive possession act. These acts are defined to include grants which con fer exclusive possession as well as crown to crown grants, those contained in the schedule of interests and areas relating to public works. We will be tackling those sorts of issues in other parts of the debate.

A claim can also not be registered if it seeks exclusive possession over an area that has at any time—I stress this—in the past or present been subject to a non‐exclusive pastoral or agricultural lease. So historic leases can have an effect that is totally unnecessary for this legislation.

We believe that the provisions proceed on a fundamental misunderstanding of the state of the common law. I do not know whether it is intentional; I suspect that it is. The government's own explanatory memorandum confirms that the question of whether native title is permanently extinguished or merely suppressed for the term of the inconsistent grant remains a question open at common law. We feel that the provision that does other than that is a massive overreach of the common law. There cannot be any justification for a prohibition on the registration of claims where it is not certain that the native title rights are inconsistent with the rights of others.

I want to go to a number of the specific parts of the test which are particularly unjust. First, the test takes into account grants which may not still be in existence. The land may be, for instance, crown land. In the absence of a clear position at common law, we believe that there is no justifiable basis upon which the right to negotiate can be denied due to some dealing with the land in an earlier part of this century or perhaps even a later part of the previous century.

Secondly, if one of these acts occurs in relation to any part—I stress this—of the claimed area, the whole claim will not be registered. You cannot justify this. Thirdly, there is to be no registration for claims over crown to crown or crown to statutory authority grants. This is due to the combined effects of sections 190B(8), 68A(2) and 23B. This is contrary to the Native Title Act, which states that a validated grant from crown to crown or crown to statutory authority does not extinguish native title but rather is subject to the non‐extinguishment principle. Again, this runs counter to the common law position articulated in Mabo No. 2.

The fourth concern in respect of this part of the test is that, as a matter of procedure, the government is making it very difficult for the Registrar to determine what are exclusive possession acts. There is no objective test to be exercised. That has to be of concern to us all. In the absence of such a test, we will get further litigation and further uncertainty.

Another problem that can be mentioned here relates to multiple claims. We know what the government is trying to do in this respect. There may, for instance, on the one hand be overlapping claims with a legitimate reason for them to be overlapping in that they may reflect the traditional law and social organisation of a particular community. But in respect of the overlapping claims provision—we will discuss it later—we do not think the government has fixed up the problem. We have amendments in respect of it that we will move later.

We should focus on the complexity and ambiguity of some of the provisions here. We should address them for a few moments. We believe that the proposed test is extremely complex. It raises a range of problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I suspect that Senator Bolkus may be dealing with the registration provisions, not the application provisions. I understand that we are moving on to applications to the Federal Court and not registration.
—That is right. I am doing that. I just want to put a bit of context into this area.
—You seem to be talking about registration, not applications.

—I will go the application provisions, as you say. It is important to put on record some of the broader concerns we have which lead up to the contextual problem we have in this area. We have about seven or eight amendments to put in respect of the application test. I do not know what attitude the government will take. There may have been an indication from them that some of them are attractive. Amendments Nos 217 and 298 make it very clear that the native title claim group includes all people who can claim to hold the particular native title. That is important in respect of some of the broader considerations I mentioned earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 229 replaces the absolute prohibition on claims over previous exclusive possession tenures and exclusive rights and non‐exclusive tenures with an obligation to adhere to the common law principles. I made that point earlier. Amendment 230 clarifies details with respect to access that was prevented. Amendment 232 allows for combined applications for determination for compensation in respect of areas within the boundaries of the area claimed for a determination of native title or, as an alternative, under section 62. Amendment 233 relates to the role and scope of authority of the registered application and ensures that it is more clearly defined. Flexibility is also provided by allowing the placement of the authorised claimant. Amendments 234 and 235 ensure that claims for a determination only do not have to be considered for registration.

We have a number of other amendments, most of which are of a consequential nature. Amendment 239, for instance, ensures representative bodies receive notice of claims. Amendment 240 is a consequential amendment to ensure that claims for a determination only do not have to be considered for registration. Amendment 243 is not to be moved. Amendment 244, in particular, leaves some necessary flexibility to the court in deciding whether to amalgamate overlapping claims.

Basically, we go to the process in the context of some of the broader amendments made by the government, but we think that our further amendments to the government's provisions actually provide for flexibility and fairness.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with government amendment No. 60.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know why we have to continue making this agreement each time. As far as I am aware, for the sake of simplicity and the committee's time, we agreed we would be able to talk to the package of amendments and then vote as required.

SPEECH.PARA: I indicate that the Greens (WA) will oppose government amendment No. 60 in relation to applications because the Greens are in favour of, or believe there is a virtue in, flexibility in making, amending and hearing applications. The government's amendment No. 60 provides yet another hurdle, yet another impediment, to the enjoyment of native title.

There is, as honourable senators will see, a conflict between the Labor amendment and the joint Greens‐Democrats amendments Nos 197 and 198. Those important issues relate to the need for current physical connection. In my opinion, the Labor amendments are still not good enough. I do not think there is a need for Labor amendments Nos 230 and 231. Therefore, when we get to that stage, I will be seeking to move amendments 197 and 198 because they omit that part of the bill requiring the current physical connection. That is going to limit many people who, for various reasons, have been kept away from their traditional lands, even if the law from those traditional lands has been passed on to current generations. It would be useful to put those first before voting on the rest of Labor's package of amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Doesn't amendment No. 60 ask, in effect, for the applicant to provide evidence, whereas most of the others, just looking through it, are simply delineating the claim with respect to which evidence is to be called?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope people are not misunderstanding amendment No. 60. What is critical in settling native title claims amicably and sensibly is to have as much information as can reasonably be obtained on the table to ensure effective mediation of claims. All that this amendment seeks is to have the applicants include in their application details of activities relating to the exercise of native title rights, so they are claiming certain native title rights. It simply asks them to give some details as to how they would propose to exercise those rights were they to receive a determination that they held those rights. Obviously, in relation to mediation of the claim, particularly where the claim involves co‐existing titleholders, as is now to be the case, it would considerably help mediation. I would have thought that all those involved in mediation should support this proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: It considerably assists mediation of the claim if the applicant has stated in the application how they would propose to exercise the native title rights and interests that they claim in their application. It seems not an unreasonable proposition. It is really all about assisting mediation of claims so they can be dealt with sensibly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to government amendment No. 60, we will not be opposing it so we do not need to prolong the debate on that unless other people have some concern.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am seeking to register the votes of the Greens (WA) and the Australian Greens on opposing government amendment No. 60.
—And likewise the Democrats.
—That will be recorded, thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to indicate our attitude, generally speaking, to the block of opposition amendments to this section. These amendments are effectively all about the Brandy amendments, the necessity to ensure proper process of bringing applications to the Federal Court in the first instance to comply with the constitutional requirements. We have no objection to amendment 230—although I think I heard Senator Margetts say that she is opposed to it—or amendment 239 of the ALP amendments. For the benefit of Senator Brown, who is not here, we are not taking a blanket opposition. Where it is clear that there is no difficulty with the acceptance of amendments, we will do so.

SPEECH.PARA: These application mechanisms and provisions do, in some way, flow from the confir mation regime. I know down the track we will have some differences of opinion on that. As I understand, the ALP remains committed to the complete removal of our provisions merely confirming that, where exclusive possession acts have taken place, they extinguish native title. Given that we are proposing a confirmation regime, therefore, the claims process should reflect that. That would mean that claims cannot be made over previous exclusive possession acts and that exclusive possession claims cannot be made over land subject to a previous non‐exclusive possession act such as a pastoral lease. In other words, you cannot have a claim accepted for exclusive possession over a pastoral lease because obviously there is someone else, a co‐tenant. That really is a very important part of our policy of bringing certainty to land management.

I was pleased to see and I welcome Mr Pearson's statement that it is unfortunate that some ambit claims are being made for exclusive possession where there are other co‐tenants of the land. This provision just ensures that, if you are claiming native title in relation to a co‐tenement, that you are not able to lodge that claim for exclusive possession but you can claim anything else.

If you are deleting the confirmation provisions and simply providing that claims must not, as far as is reasonably practical, cover an area in relation to which native title has been extinguished, which is what is being claimed here, that, from our point of view, is a much vaguer and more uncertain test and really would not be a significant hurdle for ambit claims. I suspect it starts to get us back into the one‐year problem where you will have claims being registered of dubious merit—claims being accepted, I should say. I am not talking about registration here; I am talking about acceptance of claims.

Obviously, legal consequences flow from acceptance of claims and it is most likely that, without the provisions we are proposing, or if you accept the opposition amendments, you will find that claims will be accepted, with the Federal Court taking a cautious approach in the sense that it will accept claims even where there may be absolutely no chance of ultimate success.

Some of the provisions that are proposed by the ALP are linked to the suggestion that rep bodies can certify claims and that, if so certified, these claims can be registered unless the registrar is satisfied that the representative body could not reasonably have done so. Again, we have problems in this area. While our bill significantly clarifies and expands the role of rep bodies, their principal responsibility is to be advocates for and support native title claims and it is, therefore, inappropriate that they should also have the role of assessing whether the claims they make are credible and well researched so that they should go on the register and provide to claimants the significant right to negotiate and other rights.

I also want to touch on the question of the number of native title claims in an area and determinations. We think that it is highly desirable for everybody involved in this process that there should generally be only one determination of native title for a particular area. But of course, there can be more than one group of native title holders for the area—that is self‐evident and obvious—but that the question of native title in the area should be dealt with in one determination. So there can be more than one group of native title holders for the area but, when the Federal Court is considering a claim for the area, it should consider all the claims for that area. To this extent, the role of the court is to some extent inquisitorial, which we think is desirable.

The provisions in relation to notification, parties, process and registration encourage this. Section 67 is important for this policy since it provides that the court must make orders to ensure that applications over the same area are dealt with in the same proceedings. Amendment 244 would weaken that policy by changing the `must' to `may' and therefore undermine our policy objective of seeking to ensure that all native title claims in relation to an area are dealt with in the one determination, rather than a never ending sequence of ongoing determinations.

It is one of the real theoretical problems with native title that a court hears a determi nation in relation to native title in an area but then for ever and a day you can have consequential native title claims over the same area. It is obviously good public policy for everybody concerned that, in relation to an area, everyone who claims native title is dealt with at the one time. It does not mean that the court cannot find that a number of groups claiming native title hold native title to the area. Of course, it would then be a matter for the court to determine which groups hold what title and how they interrelate. If we are all to be faced with never‐ending sequences of ongoing native title claims and determinations, many of which may cover the same area, this process will never be brought to a satisfactory resolution in everyone's interests.
