TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Harradine is actually focusing on `as far as is reasonably practicable'. Our concern with the government's 61A(2) and (3) is that they are essentially a pretty substantial overreach. Far from provid ing certainty they overreach in terms of extinguishment and probably will provide a fair degree of uncertainty as a consequence.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 229 replaces the absolute prohibition on claims over previous exclusive possession tenures and exclusive rights on non‐exclusive tenures with an obligation of adhering to common law principles. That basically sums up what we are doing. We also provide that claims should not be made in areas where native title is extinguished.

As I said earlier, what the common law has done is leave open whether in fact native title is extinguished or is suppressed for the term of an inconsistent grant. That is the question that remains open in common law. It was left open in the Wik case. The government's explanatory memorandum confirms that the common law has left it open. To the extent that the common law has left it open, there will always be a capacity for people to pursue claims for what we see, through this legislation, as unnecessary extinguishment.

You do not have to go this far. You do not have to go to the extent that the government is going. They are misrepresenting the state of the common law. Their explanatory memorandum says that. Advice from the Attorney‐General's Department on 23 January this year and even more recently in their circular has reflected that as well. Common law has not determined whether native title is permanently extinguished by a previous grant of exclusive possession or exclusive rights on non‐exclusive tenures.

That is the first concern we have. We have concerns because in, for instance, the deliberations of the Joint Committee on Native Title there was a lot of evidence showing that there had been previous exclusive possession acts, but that those acts had terminated and had run their course. Despite their having run their course, this government is trying to extinguish native title in respect of them.

We are talking about a substantial portion of land. We are also talking about, for instance, the case and the claim that was mentioned in the House of Representatives a couple of days ago by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer). The claim that has been pursued in Queensland by Noel Pearson, amongst many others, goes to an area over which there had been a number of pastoral leases. Those leases have now run their course. That land is now unallocated state land. As a consequence of that, the Cape York Land Council has put a claim in. Almost 1,500 people there have put a claim in, and Mr Pearson is one of those 1,500. If this legislation were to pass and if this particular provision were to have the effect that the government wants it to have, I think the Cape York Land Council could probably either start other proceedings or look to other areas to claim proceedings. That is just one example.

We had a lot of evidence in the Joint Committee on Native Title of examples where there had been a lease which had run its course, which was now either a ghost lease or a historic lease, and had either reverted to crown land or whatever. But, under the common law decisions of Mabo and subsequent decisions, it would be a legitimate claim for native title rights.

So not only are we concerned about the point I mentioned earlier but also we are concerned that what is covered here is historic leases as well. We also have some concern that the definition provided by the government includes grants which confer exclusive possession as well as crown to crown grants and areas relating to public works. Basically, as I said at the start, this is very much an overreach. To the extent that you might think there is certainty provided here, all these considerations I have just mentioned make it very certain that it would be uncertain, that the indigenous Australians would pursue common law claims and pursue other avenues to try to extract rights.

We also think there is no need for this. If you want to provide certainty for pastoral interests, not only do you have the protection of the common law itself in Wik, but you have other measures in the legislation—particularly the validation regime, for instance, whatever one gets up—which would provide that as well.

So, Senator Harradine, I hope this answers some of your questions. I do not know whether I have answered all of them but, in essence, we are talking here of an overreach which is, as I have often called it in the past, somewhat gratuitous extinguishment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand a lot of Senator Harradine's argument, but the conclusion is obviously something I have problems with. Senator Minchin says that, once an historic lease has lapsed, then one can claim native title.

If you think that is not an invitation to ensure further court cases, I do not know what is. In this particular case there is already an application in place. These people have exercised their rights under the existing law. If we go ahead and change that law, then a whole host of cases from Georgiardis a few years ago to Mewett now—the Voyager cases—will demand a payment of compensation. It will ensure that this particular case will finish up in the High Court, but this is just one case.

These people are exercising an existing right under the law. We are here today con templating foreclosing their capacity to pursue that right. If the government is successful here today, there will be Georgiardis, Mewett, Pearson and 1,500 others pursuing this particular case in the High Court.

I do not think in all social conscience that we could actually do that, and what for? Because someone a few years ago had a lease there. That was a few years ago. This government talks about a schedule in terms of previous leases that is so wide ranging and back reaching that it is talking about regimes that could have issued leases 150 years ago. They could be leases that expired last generation and the government cannot say that that is not the case because it does not know.

The evidence before the joint parliamentary committee made it very clear the government did not know. They are talking about ghost leases and historic leases. They have not gone through each one of them to see whether they still exist. They cannot say with any degree of certainty what lease is covered and what is not. They cannot tell us what lease has expired, because they did not go through that process one by one. They went through enabling legislation. If they thought that enabling legislation by its character was good enough and that it might have provided exclusive tenure at some stage, then they listed that. As a consequence of listing that, people lose their native title rights.

There is no uncertainty there. You cannot tell us which leases still continue, still prevail or still run. Of those leases which have expired you cannot tell us when they expired. On the basis of that you are asking us to extinguish native title. They have claims, but they have claims for what? Let us face it, you are ripping apart what they can claim for and in what circumstances they can claim.

We are talking about a not insubstantial portion of Australian land here. For instance, if you look at historic tenures in the Northern Territory some 30 per cent of the land there at some stage past was subject to a lease but is now not. How can you in all conscience say to Pearson and the others, `Okay, there was a lease there some time ago, but because of a matter of accident of history, bad luck fellas.' They will render the Mabo decision an empty shell in respect of such a great proportion of the land to which they may legitimately have a claim for native title.

You cannot do that in all conscience and you cannot in all legal certainty do it, and you know it. This is an enormous overgrab or overreach in this legislation and it is a very false one and one that really cannot in all moral conscience be substantiated, because you do not even know what particular leases you are talking about and you have not even pretended to list those tenures.

As I say, you are talking about a big area in respect of the Northern Territory and you are talking about a big area in respect of Queensland, but you are also talking about people who should have a legitimate expectation that they are able to lodge a native title claim in respect of this area after Mabo. There is another dimension to this to worry about: who is going to pay for it? Who is going to pay for this overreach? You might be worried about lawyers, Senator Harradine, but we are asking the Australian taxpayer to pay for something that they do not have to pay for. I think if honourable senators are interested in cooperation, interested in coexistence, Senator Minchin's clause here in the bill makes that possible and that is why I believe it ought to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask a question of the minister. This provision in the amendments seems to be taking the battle to the point of application rather than later on. I would like to go through that. Provision 61(5) says:

SPEECH.PARA: An application must:
(a) be in the prescribed form; and
(b) be filed in the Federal Court; and
(c) contain such information in relation to the matters sought to be determined as is prescribed; and
(d) be accompanied by any prescribed documents and any prescribed fee.

Provision 61A says that such an application must not be made in certain circumstances. If, say, an applicant goes along to the registrar and makes an application, on whom does the onus lie to see that the present provisions of 61A(2) and 61A(3) apply?

Does the registrar then have to go through an exercise to ensure that the application is in conformity with that or does the applicant have to show that? If the applicant has to show it, it seems just too great a burden. If the registrar has to show it, does it not then mean that the contest about all this land is brought to the point of application, which is a bit unusual in court proceedings, rather than to the hearing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Cooney, you have got to remember this is under the new structure to take account of Brandy. Claims are made to the Federal Court in the first instance and there is the normal Federal Court process of accepting the claims. The claims are merely accepted and it is up to somebody else if they want to come along and seek a strike‐out because they do not believe it meets these requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not sure whether the ALP is suffering a misunderstanding on this, but claims of the kind Senator Bolkus was talking about in relation to Cape York can of course be made, and they will be accepted. Claims for native title in relation to any historic leases can be made and accepted by the court in relation to current pastoral leases under these provisions—and there is no pastoral lease that is a previous exclusive possession act. That is why I think Senator Bolkus was not quite clear on what he was talking about.
There are no pastoral leases on the schedule, so claims can be made over all pastoral leases, current or historic. All it says in 61A(3) is:
If:
(a) a previous non‐exclusive possession act . . . was done in relation to an area;—
that is, pastoral leases—

a claimant application must not be made in which any of the native title rights and interests claimed confer possession, occupation, use and enjoyment of any of the area to the exclusion of all others.
So, as long as it is not claiming possession to the exclusion of all others, the claim can be accepted—and there is no difficulty there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —What I am talking about really is not so much the legal position but the matter of evidence. Who has to introduce the evidence? Section 61A talks about applications, and it says that those applications must not be made. When you look at 61A, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) a native title determination application must not be made in relation to an area for which there is an approved determination of native title.

In proposed section 23B, a series of things are set out. If a previous exclusive possession act was done to an area, and the act was attributable to the Commonwealth—and it goes through that—a claim must not be made that covers any of that area.

So you come along and say, `I want to make a claim for this area.' To be consistent with the provisions, an examination must then take place as to whether or not conditions set out in subsections (2) and (3) are made. That requires an evidentiary exercise; evidence must be taken to see whether the various provisions of 23B are set out. That is what it says: somebody has to produce evidence. Perhaps there would have to be lots of evidence because you have to knock over every part of 23B.

I want to know a couple of things. Doesn't the provision say it must not be accepted if 23B operates? Who has to prove whether 23B operates or not? Is it the registrar who gets the application? Does he or she have to go through it? In that case the court has to go through this exercise, and it is really a full‐scale hearing. Or does the applicant have to do that, in which case it seems an incredibly hard thing to ask. It would need lots of money and lots of lawyers, and the whole thing would become complicated at the point of application rather than, as you say you are trying to avoid, having problems later on.

It seems to me that in any event all you are doing is transferring your problems to an earlier point than would be the case otherwise. What does that section mean which says that the `application must not be made'? In my simple way, I take that to mean that you cannot apply if these conditions operate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I indicate a couple of things? Firstly, when I was previously speaking I indicated that I was inclined to support the bill. Clearly, that was a slip of the tongue: I am not inclined to support the bill in its entirety, of course, as people know if they have looked at the amendments I have circulated for the issues that we hope to deal with this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: Also, I have listened to Senator Cooney over too many years now delivering, in his simple way, perceptive statements relating to the law. I will be interested to have a response. At the present moment my difficulty is that we have Senator Bolkus making a statement in respect of certain claims which he indicates will be affected by this government provision, and we have Senator Minchin indicating that that is not so. We have a conflict of opinion about whether an issue is fact or whether it is not. So there is an issue of establishing what are the facts. I am not in a position to establish them at this point of time, so I think it might be desirable for this matter to be deferred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I make it abundantly clear in relation to the example Senator Bolkus raised that they are pastoral holdings which are not on the schedule, so claims can be made. There is nothing to prevent native title claims—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bolkus interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what you said—that native title claims cannot be made over those pastoral leases. Of course claims can be made over those pastoral leases, historic or otherwise. Those claims can be made.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the acceptance procedures, prima facie they will be accepted—on the face of them. Because they are going through the Federal Court, it is simply a matter for someone, if they so choose, to exercise their right to seek a strike‐out motion based on, for example, a claim for possession to the exclusion of all others in relation to something which is on the schedule, or in relation to it being a previous non‐exclusive possession act, should I say.

In all other respects the native title claim can be made in relation to the pastoral lease, historic or current. All that proposed subsection 61A(3) would do is ensure that, in relation to a pastoral lease, they can claim everything, except possession of the area to the exclusion of all others.

So there does seem to be some misunderstanding here. There is nothing in this that prevents the claims being made and accepted, and they could not be struck out if they were over pastoral leases and met the conditions of proposed subsection 61A(3). In terms of the procedures, they would simply be accepted prima facie but subject to the remedy of strike out. But you could only strike out if they did not comply with subsections (1),(2) and (3).

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, would you like to respond to Senator Harradine's point, with regard to his suggestion?
—I am not sure if I have clarified it for Senator Harradine or not. If he is still unsure about the position, I am happy to defer it.
—I know others want to speak, but I contest those facts. I will not go into the debate now. I will let others speak first and then come back into it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question for the Special Minister of State (Senator Minchin) because he is not making any sense to me. I take Senator Cooney's point. It does not seem to be very clear to me. The bill says, `Claimant applications not to be made covering previous exclusive possession act areas.' Then we have some clauses which show where an applicant can be excluded.

SPEECH.PARA: If you then go to proposed section 23B, which is the definition of a previous exclusive possession act, there are things scheduled. The minister is quoting pastoral leases, and my question to him is: what is the difference between a pastoral lease and an exclusive pastoral lease or an exclusive agricultural lease or a commercial lease that is neither an agricultural lease nor a pastoral lease?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no pastoral leases on the schedule of previous exclusive possession acts. We have gone through and scheduled all the previous exclusive possession acts and there is no pastoral lease—
—It says it in your own definition—on page 11, if it helps you.
—Your own document says that a previous exclusive possession act—
— Order! Senator Woodley, do you want to speak to the minister? If so, we will get the microphone turned on.
—I am being very naughty, and I apologise to the minister.

—There is a misunderstanding. We have drawn up a schedule of previous exclusive possession acts. If you go through that schedule, you will know that there is not one pastoral lease listed on the schedule.

SPEECH.PARA: We are merging with the debate on confirmation, which we will come to, but the confirmation provision relates to freehold or previous exclusive possession acts. They are the ones listed in the schedule, and they are primarily residential and commercial leases with some agricultural leases. But there are no pastoral leases on that schedule. Pastoral leases, therefore, are previous non‐exclusive possession acts, because in practice there are no pastoral leases in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about 23G?
—The fact is that we have not included any pastoral leases in the schedule.
—But 23G does the same thing on pastoral leases. Why don't you tell the truth?

—That is a generic description, in the event that there ever was an exclusive pastoral lease, because what the High Court said was that native title is not necessarily extinguished by a pastoral lease. That leaves open the possibility that you could find that a pastoral lease did grant exclusive possession. In terms of our confirmation provisions and their effect on the acceptance test, having gone through all the leases issued by all the states and having put them in the schedule of previous exclusive possession acts, the fact is that there are no pastoral leases scheduled.

SPEECH.PARA: This was the whole argument about the western division of New South Wales. They argued that theirs were the kind of pastoral leases that ought to be listed as previous exclusive possession acts. They were not, because we were not satisfied that they necessarily fitted in. If there is a test case or a case in relation to one of those western division leases, it may be that the court finds that they are the kind of pastoral lease that grants exclusive possession, but that is entirely a matter for the courts. The only ones that would be affected by this acceptance test, which is what we are talking about here, in terms of where claims could not be made at all, are the ones that are listed as previous exclusive possession acts, and, as I say, there is not one pastoral lease on that schedule of previous exclusive possession acts.

So, in relation to pastoral leases, claims can be made, but you cannot claim possession to the exclusion of all others. A claim for possession to the exclusion of all others could be struck out to the extent that that was the nature of the claim. You can claim everything else and have your claim accepted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I also have a question for the Special Minister of State (Senator Minchin). It does not relate to the exclusive possession section of this but to clause 3, which strikes out the possibility of an Aboriginal claimant making a claim to the exclusion of all others over an area that was previously non‐exclusive but `the act was an act attributable to the Commonwealth', and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: A great deal of the Northern Territory was originally covered by pastoral leases. Back in my CSIRO days, we consistently came across the original signs of abandoned pastoral leases. They are available in the Territory everywhere—broken‐down old horse‐drawn farm equipment and so on, stuck under trees. A great deal of the Territory was covered by these things. The Simpson Desert was covered by pastoral leases. Areas of the Western Desert were.

I might be wrong in my understanding of this, and you can correct me if I am. In the original Mabo case, as I understood it, it was determined that native title could consist of a whole range of things, from very minimal rights up to and including rights that were analogous to freehold; in other words, exclusive possession. Indeed, that is the kind of title which the claimants in the original case were able to establish over their own land. What I wanted to ask you was this, in terms of simple justice, not law: if there is an area of land in Australia that previously was covered by a pastoral lease but is now not covered by a pastoral lease and is to all intents and purposes vacant and is not being used by anybody, and if Aboriginal claimants are able to satisfy—this would be difficult, but if they were able to satisfy—a court that their occupancy and continued use and possession of the land were as good as those of the claimants in the original case, why should they not be able to make a claim over that land?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins, they can make a claim over that land. Prima facie, they can make the native title claim. The only thing that is provided for in 61A is that, if the claim is to the exclusion of all others, that part of the claim could not be accepted. They can claim everything else in relation to native title rights. That is the only part of the claim that could not be accepted; they could claim everything else. But we are actually dealing with the sort of situation I think you are suggesting by providing in our amendments for where there has been an historic lease. So they can make the claim over the historic lease; no question about that. But, where there is an historic lease and the Aboriginal people are in occupation, be it vacant crown land or whether as a reserve now on that previous lease, they can claim exclusive possession under the amendments that we are proposing. So that question you are asking about if they are occupying the land is covered by our later amendments.
—They can claim exclusive possession under your amendments?
—That is right.
—This provision has been overtaken, has it?
—I am not sure what you mean by that. What we are proposing is that—
—Which amendment overturns this?
—Proposed 47B.
—Order! If we can get the questions on the record and then get the answers on the record, it would be helpful to all of us in the longer term.
—But isn't that only in respect of Aboriginal land?

—It is 45, which inserts 47B. We are providing for two situations in relation to this question of historic leases. One is where there is an Aboriginal reserve over what was an historic lease: a claim for full possession can be made. Or, where it is vacant crown land and they are—I think the words are—`in occupation' of the land, they can make a claim for full possession. They have still got to make out their claim for the satisfaction of the court, but they would be able to make a claim for exclusive possession.

—In the terminology of Mr Fischer, I guess this is one of the first major buckets of extinguishment. It actually goes to the heart of the issue. The list on page 11 actually is quite a considerable one. With a community purpose lease, for instance, in Western Australia the issues are quite strident at the moment. We have got a current law which basically is saying that the government can compulsorily acquire land from people for private uses. Heaven knows what it is going to be like in the future. But this really is a very large list and in effect it does deliver the first bucketload of extinguishment, in any real terms. There is no reason that land which is not any longer exclusive possession should not be the subject of coexistence; no reason whatsoever. If people are not able to make an application—and that is certainly what it says—it is very hard to see how they are actually going to be able to make a claim.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to press this. If the minister can explain it, I will listen. The minister keeps saying that it is when people make an exclusive claim, but it does not say that. It simply says on page 146:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) a previous non‐exclusive possession act . . . was done in relation to an area;
a claimant application must not be made . . .
It does not say `a claimant application which is for exclusive possession'; it says that a claimant application for anything must not be made:
. . . in which any of the native title rights and interests claimed confer possession, occupation, use and enjoyment . . .
That is my problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that was accurately read. What this is saying is that 13 per cent of Australia is freehold land and about 7.7 per cent is covered by exclusive leases. That is the 21 per cent. This provision makes it clear that native title claims cannot be made over that 21 per cent of Australia. That is subsection (2). That is the effect of that. That means that the other 79 per cent can be claimed. You can claim exclusive possession over Aboriginal land or vacant crown land but, in relation to pastoral lease land, you can claim everything except possession of the area to the exclusion of all others.

SPEECH.PARA: We do have a difference of opinion on the confirmation provisions. We do say that the federal parliament has responsibility to confirm our understanding of the High Court; that, where exclusive possession has been granted, that ought to be confirmed. In our bill what we are talking about there is the 13 per cent of Australia that is freehold and the 7.7 per cent that is exclusive possession leases. The rest is open to claim, and these claim provisions, which is what we are talking about, facilitate that. The only thing it says is that in relation to a pastoral lease you can make the claim but you cannot claim it to the exclusion of all others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the myth that has been developed over the last few weeks by the government is coming to fruition. That myth is that when a native title claim is lodged—that is, when a native title claim over the land of a particular group of people is lodged—it has a mapped boundary which basically describes the area those people believe they can speak for. Given that there are various types of land tenure or ownership arrangements within that area, it is then a matter of whether or not that claim can be carried through.

SPEECH.PARA: What the government is trying to do is make it incredibly complex to make a claim—it looks something like a jigsaw puzzle. The current situation in relation to making a claim is that, as far as I understand, the onus is on the people making the claim to do the searches for ownership, exclusive possession and so on. There is not, and never has been in my understanding, the necessity for people in exclusive possession to defend their claim.

We have seen again and again over the last couple of weeks that there is an assumption and a myth that those people in exclusive possession have to defend their claim. That is what this is all about. It is all leading to this nonsense where all of this has to be done before even putting in a claim. That is going to make it so complex. Once again, it is another aspect of bucket loads of extinguishment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what these provisions do. They ensure that people occupying exclusive possession titles will not have claims made over their land. That is the effect of it. If you do not have an exclusive possession tenure and you are on a pastoral lease then a claim can be made. All this does is ensure that there is not a claim to the exclusion of all others made over it. All this does is ensure that for exclusive possession tenure, freehold and exclusive possession leases a native title claim is not able to be accepted by the court.

—I would also like to add that the government is overreaching exclusive possession. They are saying, `What used to be exclusive possession.' So it is worse than what I described; it is a jigsaw puzzle with almost no pieces left.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has told me that the new 47B provision, which I have now found and it is in a later schedule, has addressed the problem in the original amendment which concerned me. With respect, I do not think it does. As you know, Minister, I am not a lawyer, so you have to keep this simple for me. Just reduce it to terms that an uneducated mug like me can understand.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me take you through it again. When you talk about getting title to the exclusion of all others, freehold title, the original Mabo case determined that it would be possible, in justice under some circumstances, for Aboriginal people to claim a form of native title that gave them that. Indeed, that was the original title granted to the Mabo litigants—their possession to the exclusion of all others; freehold title. The concern I have—and you have confirmed it three times now—is that this new section unblushingly strikes out the opportunity that was available so far as the High Court was concerned for a native title applicant to do that.

Minister, I am not disputing at all that they can make a claim. The concern I have is that it specifies that if the claim is for exclusive possession it cannot be made. You have confirmed that three times. I have no argument with that either. You have said that section 47B fixes that up. It does not. If it does, I would like you to show me. Section 47B says:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 47B Vacant Crown land covered by claimant applications

PARA.TAB: (1) This section applies if:

TAB.TAB: (a) a claimant application is made in relation to an area; and
(b) when the application is made, the area is not covered by:
(i) a freehold estate or a lease; or
(ii) a reservation . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I have no argument with that. That makes it absolutely clear that a claim can be lodged. My problem, which this does not appear to address—and if it does, please point me to it—is that if native title claimants have the evidence, if they can prove to a court that they have precisely the same connection or an analogous connection to the land that the Mabo claimants did, why should they not be able to exercise rights they concurrently exercise and have a court give them exclusive possession?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —If you go from subsection 47B(1) to subsection 47B(2), it says:

PARA.TAB: (2) For all purposes under this Act in relation to the application, any extinguishment, of the native title rights and interests in relation to the area that are claimed in the application, by any prior act must be disregarded.

SPEECH.PARA: That means that they can make their claim for exclusive possession in relation to that area. Helpfully, it notes that obviously as a matter of common law you have to make out the fact that you have maintained your traditional connection, whatever that means—that is a matter for the courts. Subsection (2) means that the court is directed to disregard any previous act which might have extinguished native title to any extent.

TALK.START.PARA: —That being so, in order to avoid confusion for us all, are you proposing then to delete this section in the original bill—that is the one we are talking about—which completely conflicts with this new amendment? The new amendment overturns it. I accept that. Having overturned it, in order to give certainty, why don't you then simply remove it? If you let both provisions stand, they are going to fight each other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, this section needs to stand in relation to non-exclusive possession acts that are current, not historic, so that you can deal with current pastoral leases. There is a consequential amendment No. 59, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: (59) Schedule 2, item 19, page 146 (after line 25), at the end of section 61A, add:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Section not to apply in section 47, 47A or 47B cases

PARA.TAB: (4) However, subsection (2) or (3) does not apply to an application if the only previous exclusive possession act or previous non-exclusive possession act concerned was one whose extinguishment of native title rights and interests would be required by section 47, 47A or 47B to be disregarded were the application to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: So there is a consequential amendment here, subsection (4), which will be added to page 146 and will deal with your issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether my question could be looked at over the weekend; I do not want an answer now. I refer to the application to which 61A is to apply if this bill is passed. If that application is operative and, say, someone under 61A—being a person who holds a non-native title interest in relation to the whole of the area in relation to which a determination is sought, or a Commonwealth minister or, indeed, anybody there—makes an application which they must not make, what is the likely cost of gathering the evidence together and presenting that evidence in terms of showing how 23B applies or does not apply?

SPEECH.PARA: What sorts of elements should be gathered in terms of evidence and what sorts of laws should apply? What is the standard of proof that would be required and what sort of evidence should be available or not available to the court? Do strict rules of evidence apply? What would the cost of all that be, not only in terms of presentation but also in terms of preparation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The normal Federal Court rules would operate. These are Federal Court matters. This is one of the many matters which the Federal Court will now be dealing with as a matter of law. The normal strike-out provisions will apply. It would be a matter for someone who wishes to seek a strike-out, as they can with any matter before the Federal Court, to establish to the satisfaction of the court that the claim should be struck out. They are the ones who will have to bring the evidence to the court and satisfy the Federal Court's normal evidentiary rules and requirements that the matter should be struck out.

—In those circumstances, how can you say that this provision makes things simpler or cheaper since the very thing you were trying to avoid is brought into operation by the section? How does it become cheaper and quicker?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, this is a consequence of the Brandy decision. I appreciate that the former Labor government—I understand the reasons—did want to have native title dealt with by a specialist tribunal and dealt with in a way which it thought at the time might actually work. But the High Court said in the Brandy decision, `Sorry, this is one of the areas where the Native Title Act is unconstitutional.' To the extent that it set up a mechanism whereby applications were made to the Native Title Tribunal for determination, it is unconstitutional.

SPEECH.PARA: We are doing this because of the constitution requiring that only the Federal Court can make determinations of native title. This is an application for determination and it must be made to the Federal Court. This is the whole point of all these amendments. We are retaining the Native Title Tribunal, as you all agree, and its role becomes essentially mediation. It becomes a mediation service of the Federal Court. The claims are referred to the tribunal for mediation. To the extent that the right to negotiate process is triggered, that is handled through that process. But Brandy requires that applications be made to the Federal Court and the normal Federal Court rules apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —If that is so and it is not going to make all that much difference in terms of cost and time taken, why are we going through the pain of leaving 61A(2) and (3) in if at the end it is not going to make much difference in terms of cost, time, the sort of evidence you have to gain and the work that is available to lawyers?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, 61A(2) and (3) are to implement government policy. Where it is clear is a matter of our understanding of the common law—that is, where there is exclusive possession, native title has been extinguished and native title claims should not proceed. When the Native Title Act was passed, we were dealing with 37 per cent of Australia. We are now dealing with 79 per cent of Australia. Claims can be made.

SPEECH.PARA: You seem to be missing the point. All this is saying is that exclusive possession exists over 21 per cent of Australia. This mechanism is the mechanism by which government policy is implemented and claims should not be made over that 21 per cent—that exclusive possession tenure. But on the other 79 per cent, claims can be made through this process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the suggestion made by Senator Harradine a little while ago is probably a good one. It seems like the government has taken a very long and winding road, and we are a bit concerned that you might have been taken some short cuts through it. I would like the opportunity to look at this over the weekend.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to take up Senator Harradine's suggestion, particularly because, as Senator Minchin keeps on saying, this is consequential to the confirmation of extinguishment. It is probably important for us to keep that in mind and maybe come back to it after we have considered confirmation of extinguishment, given the fact that we probably need a little while over the weekend anyway to consider how it all meshes together and what may not be picked up and what some of the other unintended gaps may be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened carefully to the debate. Some of the matters that were raised by the opposition—at times rather vigorously—I believe have been disposed of by the minister. I am happy to go along with what Senator Bolkus is now suggesting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to postpone consideration of opposition amendment No. 229.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will now deal with the rest of the opposition amendments moved by Senator Bolkus.
—As I said earlier, I do not think I need to speak to them, but that was before a two hour debate intervened. I do not know if anyone has any other concerns with respect to that.
—I put the question that the further amendments moved by Senator Bolkus be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think we will divide at this time of the day. But were it somewhat earlier and another day we probably would have divided.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (197) Schedule 2, item 19, page 147 (lines 16 to 25), omit paragraph (c).
(198) Schedule 2, item 19, page 149 (lines 17 and 18) omit ", and may contain the details that would be permitted under paragraph (1)(c),".

I can count, and I think everybody in the Senate can count. The vote of the Senate in relation to opposition amendment 230 and government amendment 60 was clear. I mentioned at the time that they were more impediments, more hurdles and more restrictions to the enjoyment of native title. I think it is necessary to put what is the compromised position—the position that has been worked out with the national indigenous working group—on the table, put it to the vote and make it clear that that is, if you like, the line that they have indicated to us as their preferred position.

I basically omit the section in the bill requiring the remnant physical connection because of the injustices which have occurred, which we all know of—that is, where people have been restricted because of the unfairness of a situation where there may well have been somebody only a couple of years ago who was still alive but the law has been passed on. Therefore, what we are seeing is a further removal of the enjoyment of native title rights. I would still like to persist with amendments 197 and 198, which I have moved in the name of the Greens and the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly support that. Obviously, I am going to make a much longer speech when we come to the issue of the registration test. But the whole issue of requiring a physical connection before any claim can be advanced, even though there are certain exclusions being proposed by different people, is quite abhorrent to me. I will make that clear when we come to the whole issue of the registration test.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we perhaps debated these things the wrong way round. I think we should have debated the registration test before we debated the whole issue of the applications, because then what we are doing would have been clearer. But there is no point in including in an application a physical connection test if you do not believe there ought to be a physical connection test at all, which is the belief I have. I think it is important to raise here, just in this particular issue, why it is that we are insisting on this amendment which would knock out of the application process any requirement for a physical connection test.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a point of clarification, I did say requiring remnant physical connection. I want to correct that. There is a section that gives the expectation that it will be required because it is in there. We believe, as I mentioned earlier, that that would lead to a situation where there was a requirement. But it does actually say `require' at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is to do with applications, of course, at the Federal Court stage. It simply says `that claimants may'. There is absolutely no requirement upon them to do any of those things. This is an option for the claimants to include that information if they so choose. I will not try to delude you. Obviously, there is some relevance to the registration test, but this is not a requirement of having your claim accepted by the court. If you do not contain any of these details, that does not go to harm your claim whatsoever.

SPEECH.PARA: We will have the discussion about the registration test. We are including in the registration test a requirement that one member of the claim group must have or have had that physical connection. In other words, to get registered, to attract all the benefits of the right to negotiate and all that sort of thing, if there is a claim group of 300 or something, all we are saying in the registration test is that one member should currently have or have had at any stage in their life a physical connection to the land claim—which does not seem unreasonable given that, to prove your native title claim, the court has said that you have got to have maintained a traditional connection to the land.

I do not want to be accused of any deception here. This section does have some relevance for the purposes of the registration test, but is in no way linked to it in that sense. It is simply inviting the claimant, when they are lodging an application, to include such details if they so choose. If they do not, it will not affect the claim in any way at all in relation to its acceptance by the Federal Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —What the minister says is not quite getting to the point in relation to the way courts deal with those kinds of issues. What if you put it in conjunction with the fact that this government is saying that they want one application, they want to be able to hone down the number of applications? If you have two applications and one has evidence of physical connection and one has not, it would be like an application for a job. On the application you put in, `Skills in this may be useful or may be of benefit.' Then when you get down to it you can pick off the ones that do not have that in. The courts will be influenced by whether or not those elements are in the application. Considering this government is picking winners by way of applications, trying to put everybody on one claim, I can well see that the court will actually be likely to exclude claims because they do not come up to that mark—even with that word `may'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not an application for a job. We are not dealing with 10 people applying for one job. We are dealing with applications to the court for determinations of native title. Whether there is one or 1,000, as long as they meet the bare minimum requirements, which at the application stage are bare minimum requirements, the claim is accepted. All this does is say that that claim may contain these details.

SPEECH.PARA: I really do suggest that you are reading far too much into it and jumping at shadows. It is self-evidently something that is entirely a matter for the claimants and will not affect their claim.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to endorse what Senator Margetts and Senator Woodley have been saying. This section is not here to fill up space. It is here to encourage applicants to give the details not just of their physical connection with the land that is under claim but of their traditional physical connection and any reason as to why that has been prevented. It is already one step towards saying, if you cannot show that, you are in a different category. The minister may shake his head, but that is exactly what the intention is here. It is a deterrent for people who cannot meet clearly or easily the requirements of 621C and it puts them in another category. This is a moot point. It is one of these indefinable clauses which are sectioning people out, which are qualifying claims. That is why we are worried about it. The alarm bells are ringing.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no mention of spiritual connection here. Maybe that should have been mentioned. We are not dealing with just the physical world when it comes to Aboriginal claims to land. We are dealing very much with spiritual connection. Why isn't there a section here which says that the claimants may be able to show a traditional spiritual connection with the land that is under claim? That would have shown a bit more understanding by the people who have drawn up these amendments, namely, the government. But it is not here.

We are getting ourselves on the road towards the impossibility of or, more pertinently, the unfairness in people who have seen forcible dispossession in their history over the last 200 years approaching the claims through application and raising their rights to proceed through to the point where they see a claim validated.Why is there no reference to the spiritual or cultural connection with the land here? Why is just the physical connection mentioned? That is a central point of this process we are dealing with. The Aboriginal people I speak to repeatedly come back to that spiritual connection with the land.

The European history is one which deals with physical disconnection because there was no understanding of the spiritual connection, but here we are seeing in this amendment that physical connection being required. But we know that that is going to be an impediment to some people considering whether or not they can make a claim. I just make that point in supporting what the previous speakers in this corner of the chamber have said. I do question the minister as to why the spiritual connection has not been put in along with the physical connection. Was it considered not worthy of mention in the same paragraph?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to Senator Brown's question, this section does not require the claimants to establish in any way either a spiritual or a physical connection for the purposes of having their claim accepted. They get accepted at the Federal Court and then they can proceed with their claim for a determination that they hold native title. It is entirely left to the courts at to whether or not the claimants have established the traditional connection, whatever that means—that is a matter for the courts.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Brown is quite right to state that many Aboriginal people would assert that, when it comes to establishing to the satisfaction of a court that they have maintained their connection, a spiritual connection will suffice. That is left by this entirely. That is why we are not requiring them at this stage to satisfy either a spiritual or physical connection—because that is left entirely to the courts. They simply lodge their application, they are required to give a bit of information, but their claim then just proceeds through the Federal Court to the question of determination.

However, certainly most people agree that, when it comes to the registration of a claim for the purposes of access to the statutory right to negotiate and other statutory benefits, people go from the application level up to the registration test. There is general agreement that we need to have a more robust registration test so that when the right to negotiate process is triggered everybody involved in the right to negotiate process knows they are dealing with fair dinkum claimants who are likely to succeed in their claim.

As I said before, at the level of the registration test, not at the application level, one of the elements of the registration test that we are proposing is that one member of the claim group—and, as I say, we do not put any limit on the size of the claim group; it could be 10,000 people—must have or have had a traditional physical connection. We are not even saying what that is—that is a matter for the registrar.

We are just saying that claimants who lodge an application may then wish to have it registered, so at the stage of the application they then at that point include any details relating to any physical connection they may have had. They do not have to. If they are not interested in registration, it does not matter a bar at all—they just proceed with their claim and it is a matter for the court as to whether a determination that they hold native title is made. We are not at this stage putting anything in the way of that. It is simply that, if they then wish to move to registration, they have already included in their application the relevant information. They are not required to do it at that stage under our process, which no doubt you will oppose later. At the registration test level we are saying the registrar needs to be satisfied that one member had at some time in the past or currently has that physical connection.

So all we are saying is that we are offering them the opportunity at this stage of the process to include such information in their claim, but the absence of such information will have absolutely no bearing whatsoever on the acceptance of their claim in the Federal Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the minister about the spiritual connection. Why not the spiritual connection? Why does that not have weight or value here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —It may well have weight and value for the Federal Court. What we are saying is that we are not requiring applicants to say anything about their physical or spiritual connection to the land when they make their application for native title. They have to establish that to the satisfaction of the court, and we leave that entirely to the courts. The only reason this is here is that, if they wish subsequently to have their claim registered for the purposes of the right to negotiate and all those things, this is an opportunity they have to include in their claim at this point such information. But the absence of it will not affect in any way their claim for a determination for native title.

—Considering the love affair this government seems to have with the word `certainty', I just wonder for the purpose of certainty how long it will take before we have a further Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 amendment which replaces the word `may' with `must'. It is a matter of time, given the way the government is going at the moment. But it is also an opportunity to challenge the ALP as well. I indicate that I will be seeking to divide on this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Greens are going to divide on it, they will. But, with respect to Senator Margetts and Senator Brown, I support Senator Minchin on this particular matter. Senator Brown, you are reading too much into this particular proposed section, which is about application and not registra tion. The minister can correct me if I am wrong, but I simply saw these prescriptive elements as being the absolute minimum required and not in any sense weighting the value of physical as against spiritual or anything else. So, in relation to Senator Margetts's concern about `may' being changed to `must' at some future date, I am perfectly happy to concentrate on the 700 amendments we have in front of us now before Christmas and worry about that when it happens.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the President, upon notice, on 18 November 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can you confirm that an application was received from Boxing Holdings Pty Ltd trading as I'm Gayme to hold a fund raising event in the Great Hall of Parliament House entitled The Gayme Jamaican Ball on the 22 November 1997 for the Canberra Gay and Lesbian QWIRE and the A.C.T. Aids Council.
(2) What is the status of this application.
(3) Is it true that the application has been rejected.
(4) If so, on what ground(s) was this application rejected.
(5) Has the applicant been informed in writing and if not why not.
(6) Is it true that Mr Fraser Bradley, Assistant Secretary of the Joint House Department informed Mr Gary Frost, the event organiser, that an objection was received to the application.
(7) If so, who was the person(s) who lodged the objection? Please provide a copy of the objection or records of conversations of the objection to this application.
(8) Is it true that Mr Gary Frost was informed by Mr Fraser Bradley or by the Hyatt that a formal application was not needed until more formal numbers were confirmed.

(9) Is it true that Mr Fraser Bradley informed Mr Gary Frost that the reasons for the rejection were that: (a) not approved by a majority of Members of Parliament, (b) inconsistent with the dignity of the federal Parliament, (c) or likely to cause offence to any significant part of the Australian community.
(10) Do you object to Lesbian and Gay organisations using Parliamentary facilities. If so, on what grounds.

(11) Please provide a list of organisations or individuals which have been approved and/or have used the great hall in the past five years as well as a list of organisations or individuals who have been rejected and the names of members of Parliament who have sponsored such applications.
(12) Can you confirm that the organisers for this event have lost or stand to lose upwards of $6,000.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Oral representations were received on 8 September 1997 from Mr Gary Frost, of the I'm Gayme Organisation, who requested a prospective booking to use the Great Hall on 22 November 1997. An information package, comprising Terms and Conditions, menus, and an application pro‐forma, was sent to Mr Frost on 8 September. The Hyatt contacted Mr Frost on 9 October, seeking a written application. This written application to the Hyatt was received from Intro‐Gateway Introduction Consultation, I'm Gayme only on 12 November 1997, just 10 days prior to the scheduled function.
(2) The application was withdrawn by Mr Gary Frost of the I'm Gayme Organisation on Friday 14 November 1997.
(3) No. While the application was not supported by the Joint House Department, the Presiding Officers were still considering the application at the time that it was withdrawn.
(4) Not applicable.
(5) Not applicable.
(6) Mr Bradley informed Mr Frost that a private citizen had called the Joint House Department office expressing concern at the proposed function.

(7) The person was a private citizen who saw a flyer advertising the Ball and contacted the Joint House Department to complain. Another person also complained about the flyer. They did not want their names mentioned.

(9) Mr Bradley at no stage told Mr Frost that his application had been rejected. Mr Bradley informed Mr Frost that he had advised the Presiding Officers he had recommended against the function, and that the Presiding Officers were not inclined to approve the function. This was based on information then available to the Presiding Officers as to the nature of the function.
The Terms and Conditions for the Use of Parliament House Facilities stipulate that non‐Parliamentary functions must be judged as being of a nature that would be:
. approved by the majority of members of Parliament.
. consistent with the dignity of the Parliament.
. unlikely to cause offence to any significant part of the Australian community.

These Terms and Conditions were sent to Mr Frost on 8 September 1997, and he again received the criteria through the office of the Honourable R. McMullan MP on 14 November. Mr Frost, in discussions with Mr Bradley on 17 November, acknowledged that he had been aware of the Terms and Conditions for the Use of Parliamentary Facilities.
(10) No. The basis of approval or not for any function to be held in Parliament House is the assessment of the particular function against the criteria stated above.
(11) This question is presently being considered, but I am not satisfied that the significant amount of work involved can be justified.

(12) Neither the Joint House Department nor the Presiding Officers are aware of the financial situation of the organisers, nor of any loss that may have been incurred as a consequence of the withdrawal of the application.
